MARS ATTACKS! wastes no time whatsoever establishing its own intentions: we see a pair of rural neighbors exchanging pleasantries. One of the two gets a whiff of something and realizes that they must be standing downwind of a barbecue. Before you can say "pile it on a plate," a herd of burning cattle comes thundering over the horizon. If THAT doesn't make clear the filmmaker's intentions, nothing could. Tim Burton pokes loving fun at- of all things- a series of bubble gum cards from the 1960s- and he does it brilliantly. A former friend whose tastes run to just about everything every filmmaker has ever produced told me that he "hates" this movie. I've frankly never been able to figure out why: it has ALL of the elements he loves so much in so many lesser efforts. Only done far better. Looking at the info provided on this site, I see that the original cards were written by one Len Brown. I wonder if this is the same Len Brown who served as the model for Wally Wood's Len Brown- Dynamo- in the old Tower comics...?

Review title: Burton Attacks! an array of different ideas; genres and spoofs as smiles, scares and generally scattered content play out under a familiar set-up.
Review_body: Tim Burton's 1996 film Mars Attacks! might just be one of the most shameless films ever made. The picture is shameless in its pastiching of those old, 1950s B-Movie sci-fi films; it's shameless in its convoluted and relatively misguided content, which constantly jumps from that of a seemingly harmless and 'funny' nature to out and out shock tactics; and it is pretty shameless right the way down to its casting of Pierce Brosnan as the British, typically cleverer than everyone else, pipe-smoking scientist character amongst many other issues I have with the portrayal of those in supporting roles. The crazy thing is, that everything just about comes together and everything just about works thanks to some minor, more minute observations of the world in which we live and the attitudes we express.As has been noted on many an occasion by those in the past, director Burton jumped into Mars Attacks! ,a spoofing of old Hollywood B-Movies, following 1994's Ed Wood which was about a man made famous by those exact things. Half of Tim Burton's CV sees him do adaptations of some kind, that's what he does when he isn't dabbling in expressionistic inspired; Gothic infused dream-like projects such as Beetlejuice; Edward Scissorhands; Sleepy Hollow and, with hindsight, something like Corpse Bride. The adaptation-inspired side of his work sees him remake past films in Planet of the Apes and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory; adapt stage shows in Sweeny Todd and, perhaps most famously, bring to life the Batman comics. Mars Attacks! is a curious beast; it's a sort of satire-come-loose remake of most 'flying saucer' movies from decades ago, but doubles up as some sort of visualisation-come-adaptation of a series of somewhat frightening trading cards, additionally from decades ago. There are times it works, times it doesn't.The film is a mixture of filmic awareness combining with the showing off of special effects to deliver something that caters to most tastes: it is scary; funny, but only in the blackest of forms; carries a fair amount of suspenseful content and is relatively unpredictable given its complete disregard to famous acting names and faces in terms of whether character and actors are powerful enough, important enough or recognised enough in order to survive. Observing some of the more powerful acting heavy weights drop out of the film as those we've never heard of charge through, scathed but alive, is quite amusing.The film has a premise, I'm not sure about it having an actual narrative, but it has a premise none-the-less. And that is that extra-terrestrials from another planet are about to arrive on planet Earth with the apparent intent to destroy everything in sight: buildings; landmarks; people; cattle; everything. The invading force don't seem to give a reason for their actions, but the tag-line informs us of their thoughts: "Nice planet. We'll take it!" which would suggest they want to invade and set up their own settlements, indeed this was the aim in the trading card series. Indeed, the notion of what they want calls to mind that somewhat silly scene from 1996's Independence Day in which the president of the United States is told, telepathically, what it is the invading alien force are doing on Earth. You feel there must've been a point in which, amongst all the fun in making the film or writing the screenplay; someone must've just sat up suddenly and thought "Hell, what beef do these creatures even have with Earth? Why are they even doing this?" Answer? Because their actions spawn explosions and war, and that makes money at the box-office.Mars Attacks! covers a variety of different characters, too many if we're honest, and most of them are either clichés or stereotypes. You have the struggling African-American family, which features real-life ex-NFL player Jim Brown playing an ex-boxer named Byron Williams, with wife Louise (A pre Jackie Brown Pam Grier), whose kids are underwritten layabouts with a fascination for guns which eventually sees them acting as bodyguards for The President. Then you have the trailer-park dwelling Southerners; the prim, cell phone sporting, chihuahua owning socialite-turned-TV presenter in Sarah Jessica Parker's Nathalie Lake; while the Eastern European (mad?) scientist, whom creates a Martian translation device, is a sloppy representation too far.But there's a sly streak to the piece; something very dark which will see a well-off and pretty powerful character cruise the streets, in their chauffeur driven limousine, abuse the access they have to certain places as they look for women whom they can pay for sex. Later on, this character will suffer a cruel downfall when their sexual activeness goes a step too far and they perish. On another strand, a hotel businessman in Las Vegas seems to embody the very notion of greed as this additionally rich and rather well off character is naive as to what's around them in relation to the invading alien force, whom he thinks can be bargained with. This case-study of lust, greed and the abusing of one's position of power are slight but sly.While the film is nowhere near anything brilliant, there are enough little things to keep it going. The early banter between the American generals is quite funny and Michael J. Fox's character's fondness for a rival, female TV presenter is quite sweet. The film eventually settles for a vulnerable, but caring and therefore likable lead whose fearless dedication to aid those around him sees him win through. There are a few wavy moments; such as the scene in which a character is kept alive by God knows how when his disconnected head is kept suspended in the air as his heart, wired up a few feet from him, keeps beating as he talks to a human/dog hybrid; while there aren't nearly enough guerrilla scenes later on when a band of survivors make their way through the ruins of a city. But what works, works well and it's just about worth seeing.

This is a strange movie: In a way, it's as deadly serious as others extraterrestrial invasions (see "ID4") but in the same time, it's totally irreverent. In a way, it's a cousin of Spielberg's "1941". The humor comes from the Martian that are really sadistic and childish but also from the stupidity of humans. For me, it was cool to see that wasn't any respect for institutions and it's a welcomed breath of air from the always docile movies: here, POTUS isn't a courageous pilot, his Lady wears Prada, dogs are killed, monuments are destroyed, army is defeated and so on. On the other side, the movie has flaws as well: the entire Vegas situation is boring, all the more that a lot happens here. The miraculous song is really irritating (i understand why Martians react this way!). However, the cast is top notch and it's unusual to see such great names in one movie. In addition, the production is beautiful and very colorful and Danny's score is really entertaining!If you are stiff-necked or conservative, this is not a movie for you. If you aren't, you will have fun, I think. To conclude in the same spirit of the movie, I remember that the movie was scheduled on French TV on September 2001 but was then canceled!

Cool comedy takes the best comedy cast since the heyday of 70s road films and pits them against bubble-headed aliens out to conquer earth.  Some memorable comedy moments help the film pass through its less funny periods. Pretty amazing, gory effects.  Nicholson turns in a great double performance; Fox also fills in an early bit but falls prey to the aliens fairly early on.  Portman shows off her trite character acting as the President's daughter.  Contains some very funny commentary on American society in the best 50s monster tradition of the true at heart surviving over the weak, uninspired empire.

This is another under the radar gem I really like, yeah, I'm a fan of the 50's Topps serialized trading card line, which were beautiful oil painted illustration of simply aliens invading earth and us either getting killed or fighting back. That was it in a nutshell just turn your brain off mayhem. This film I feel captures that, despite not meeting every expectation this film came pretty close.The film is a parody of the 50's sci-fi from the good to even the ones you might have seen on "Mystery Science Theater 3000". As well as most of the Irwin Allen disaster films he was most famous for. It's not exactly one of the best parody films I've ever seen but it's solid.I really like the effects which are a combination of both CGI and practical which I feel actually hold up pretty well today. The aliens look just like the ones on the cards silly and butt ugly at the same time. Along with the technology like the giant robot which are always my favorites. And even like the laser effects and the way the people die, despite not gory it still looks brutal.I love the manic campy dark humored fun this film has, the whole film in a way plays out like a Mad Magazine cartoon, as each of the random things the Martians do are almost like comedy skits. From simply killing people in creative random ways like using one of the big robots to destroy a trailer with people we don't like which was a satisfying payoff. Commit petty vandalism, tour, you name it. I even like that the martians have comical personality which I feel fit them perfectly because like with the cards we're not meant to take them seriously. These guys are pretty much jerks, that you love to dislike both taking over the planet while fraking around and having fun in the process.Also I like the amount of clever humor it has, not just in visuals but verbal. The verbal humor is just fraking hilarious were the dialog is deliciously bad, some of the things certain random human characters say and even the Martian's sometimes can make you both laugh and groan at the same time. It's kinda funny because it's true in most disaster or badly made alien invasion flicks, sometimes they would have that dialog no matter how chessy or bad it was, some lines they said were fondly memorable.Even the human characters are fun, okay I wouldn't say their characters their more like charachures and that's the point. Just like in the cards their all one or two dimensional characters, and most of them are as moronic as most of the populace of "South Park", which of course make the Earth all the more ripe for take over. I like that they have a little personality and also the fact that it consists of a really huge A list cast which is both surprising but makes it all the more funny as each of them are just hamming and cheasing up the caricature's they play. It's also funny because most disaster films from Irwin Alien always consisted of a big A list cast for some weird reason.Really like the young main protagonist played by Lucas Haas along with his grandma. Both have a good back and forth, and I like the fact that in a way she's a better parent than his real parent whom are a couple of unlikable lowlifes. The grandma says one of my favorite lines, "They killed Congress." I couldn't help but crack up a bit from the way she said it but also something in the dark part of my mind I'd love for aliens to do since we have one too many corrupt politicians in the cabinet already.Jim Brown along with Pam Grier are really solid and it was great seeing both of them together once more since both are Blackpotation alumis, though I don't think and even they didn't think it would be this movie which make it all the more funny. Really like that their kids are bad asses as we see both get the aliens guns and are actually kicking more ass than the secret service, for a highly trained protection force they really suck. And liked it when Jim Brown was fist fighting against one of the aliens and breaking the glass, he could almost be like a Shonan anime protagonist because he's got some super human knuckles to be breaking though glass without getting cut.Rod Steiger as a over the top gung ho general along with Jack Nickelson as the president are just hilarious. From seeing the General so determined to kill the aliens. Down to the President trying to keep the peace despite failing miserably at it, my favorite line was "there are still two branches of government still working and that's not bad." um yeah it is.I'd love to see another Mars Attacks film with the R rating, it could be even darker more true to the card line but also still have that campy black humor. Or better yet a TV series on the Adult Swim block on "Cartoon Network" where each season could be a serialized plot and each episode a random nutty situation to deal with or even go the anthology and part of it could be the martians crossing over with other shows (if live action they be in animated form) like Gravity Falls, Steven Universe, Doctor Who, you name it it would be a laugh riot. Just a thought.Mars Attacks is out of this world and then some.Rating: 3 stars

Despite anything, (Independence Day - 1996) was a milestone in the "end-of-the-world" disaster movies. Yes, it's all about Viva America and marvelous CGI. Yes, it has some plot holes and tons of silliness. Yes, I didn't like a lot of things in it, or even didn't like it. However, it had smash success, and it did affect many movies to come.The thing is (Mars Attacks! - 1996) came out 5 months later. And with its publicity, it looked like another (Independence Day) yet with more stars and comedy. But that wronged it highly, because it is - in fact - the negative version of (Independence Day). And with regard to photography terms, the "negative" is always ugly however truer.(Mars Attacks!) is shocking. This round, there are nearly no heroes, the disaster smashes the world, and there is - to my surprise, and the genre's as well - a message.In an exceptional way, the movie utilized the "disaster" for satirizing the American society at the moment. Look how all the greedy, stupid, and coward characters are destroyed easily. And how the sole way to survive is by being less materialistic and more spiritual, as pellucid and high as the ancient music. Simply the movie dealt with America as an invaded place already by so many lethal values, to become a big joke in the movie's conscience.I loved many smart touches along the way. For instance: The Press Secretary, played by Martin Short, due to being a sex maniac, brings the Martians to the White House itself! The end's platonic love story between Professor Kessler, played by Pierce Brosnan, and TV host Nathalie, played by Sarah Jessica Parker, with no human bodies / destructive lusts involved. The old and tired boxer Byron Williams, played by Jim Brown, hated his job's dirty work, and became a Muslim; and having a real spiritual faith in this movie equals surviving; which Byron wins in the end.Jack Nicholson plays the American President James Dale, and the dull cowboy, showy hustler, Art Land who believes in money only. Since the first viewing, I believed that that was intended as the ultimate satire towards the American President in general, as if Art Land is his mirror reflection as dull cowboy, showy hustler, who believes in money only!The Martians were another wicked reflection in this movie's mirror. They are the humans, the real ugly picture of them as horny, lair, and avid people. Scrutinize a little, and you'll discover that their insane look, vain manners, and endless violence were ours. They're even short to embody our weakness, or assure how we're just dwarfs in that incredibly gigantic universe.All the cast did fine, and were so amusing. Though, I see that 2 actors stood alone: Rod Steiger as General Decker, who was a great caricature of the American military arrogance, being the movie's top laugh for me. And the impressive 85 year old Sylvia Sidney as Grandma Florence. That veteran actress, who began her career in the 1920s, and worked with director Tim Burton before in Beetlejuice (1988), delivered no acting at all; and this is the hardest acting of all!Burton, and his team of writers, were the actual Martians. They exposed the characters' frailty, and killed them for a laugh. Though, they were better than the Martians eventually, since they warned us: "Don't you dare let this happen again!".But nobody wanted to see the ugliness, laugh at the joke, or hear the warning. Because (Mars Attacks!) was too harsh to be the dreamy disaster movie, being about the defeat more than the victory. Add to that, the disappointing fact of it as a black comedy not an action (so how about having very little comedy as well!). That's why it wasn't a critics' favorite at the time, and grossed $101 million out of $100 million budget!Despite its dark tone, lack of comedy, and reputation as a flop, I enjoy such a movie. Enough to tell you that I've watched it many many times. It has bitter imagination, and pessimistic vision, but it managed to be optimistic at the end; at least the world there became more pure without its greedy, stupid, and coward characters!This is an anti-(Independence Day) movie. And I love it for all the reasons that I hate (Independence Day) for!

Review title: A Sci-Fi Satire With A Hidden Agenda
Review_body: *Possible Spoilers!* "We come in peace!"Mars Attacks was a totally "cool" way for director Tim Burton to annihilate such despicable big-name actors as Jack Nicholson, Danny DeVito, Jack Black, Sarah Jesica Parker, Glenn Close, Michael J. Fox and Martin Short (Phew! What a list of all-star casualties, eh!?) - And have a helluva lot of fun dong it.I only wish that Burton had also managed to have that annoying flake, Annette Bening, gunned down and vaporized, as well.Hideous-looking alien-bastards from Mars (vicious, cruel, and deceptive), toting insta-fry ray guns, land on Earth, and after hoodwinking the gullible public into thinking that this is a visit of friendship, commence with a horrific attack of mass-destruction, blowing up everything in site to smithereens.Can nothing save Earth from these ugly, bubble-headed, little creeps and their nasty, sadistic destructiveness?? Well, little do these menacing Martian-midgets know that we have discovered our very own secret weapon against them that's even more devastating than all of the nuclear weapons in the world.Yes. Indeed.And, who would've ever thought that Grandma Norris's "Slim Whitman" records would actually serve as our only defense against the Martians and inevitably save the day? I found this Sci-Fi/Comedy/Action film from 1996 to be a really uncharacteristic picture from Tim Burton.Presented as a tribute to 1950's UFO movies, Mars Attacks (with its awesome visual effects) delivers a kooky blend of twisted humor and ultra-violence that, when it works (which is about two-thirds of the time), is guaranteed to put a smile on the face of any fan of B-Movie schlock.P.S. - Yes, I do agree that, when it came to bad taste, Burton certainly did push the limits when he had the Martians perform their head-transplanting job, using Poppy, the cute, little, bug-eyed chihuahua, in their awful experiment.

Review title: Interplanetary war reduced to a virtual joke.
Review_body: This is a goofy movie, a spoof on the science fiction genre, and it works. The story has huge holes in it and could easily be trashed, but would not deserve it because this movie is fundamentally a science fiction black comedy. To take this movie seriously is a useless exercise in futility. Why trash a movie that's not supposed to be taken seriously? With that understanding, these comments are offered. Jack Nicholson plays two characters and provides an interesting and at times quite amusing performance. Jack Black and Sarah Jessica Parker also provide entertaining performances. But the best performance of all was that of Rod Steiger. Indeed, Mr. Steiger could have played Mr. Nicholson's roles too. The story is a take-off on other sci-fi movies but also includes some originality so that the movie is more than just a mere rehash of previous works. The movie may have some similarities to, let's say, The War of the Worlds, but is definitely NOT a remake of that movie. This movie also relies heavily on special effects which is a key component of the story. If you are searching for a movie that reduces interplanetary war to a virtual joke, then this movie is for you. But remember, it's only a movie.

Review title: American director Tim Burton allows ghoulish martians to mess around with human brains.
Review_body: "Mars Attacks" is one of those ordinary films meant for one time viewing only which has been lucky enough to have achieved an almost cult film status as people have tried to decipher purposeful truths from it.All this has happened as its creator Tim Burton has created one of the most grotesquely strange films ever made in the history of cinema.One of the most challenging lessons that can be learned from this film involves the so called fictional failure of great American nation.This is something which helps viewers to deduce that modern man is nothing but a minuscule puppet who always exposes himself to annihilation at the hands of mysterious forces of nature who may arrive without any imminent warning from a distant,unknown planet.A fairly good idea of American unity is portrayed by using a good cast involving some of the biggest names of Hollywood cinema.However,this cast remains wasted as Tim Burton makes a fairly valiant attempt to make audiences pamper with his absent minded jokes.Most of this film's scenes are a veritable assault on human intelligence as aliens have been duly depicted as real stars who make a true mess of human life.It is hard to digest the fact that such events take place in one of the strongest nation on planet earth.

A fleet of Martian spacecraft surrounds the world's major cities and all of humanity waits to see if the extraterrestrial visitors have, as they claim, "come in peace." U.S. President James Dale receives assurance from science professor Donald Kessler that the Martians' mission is a friendly one. But when a peaceful exchange ends in the total annihilation of the U.S. Congress, military men call for a full-scale nuclear retaliation.Director: Tim Burton
Writers: Jonathan Gems, Len Brown, Woody Gelman, Wally Wood, Bob Powell, Norman Saunders
Starring: Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Bening, Pierce Brosnan, Danny DeVito, Martin Short
Producers: Tim BurtonTim Burton made this sci-fi comedy called Mars Attacks!, and the cast he brought with him will make your eyes water. Seriously, the list is impressive. Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Bening, Pierce Brosnan, Danny DeVito, Martin Short, Sarah Jessica Parker, Michael J. Fox, Natalie Portman, Christina Applegate, Pam Grier, Jack Black... and I've left some out ! It's like an Avengers movie if the superheroes were replaced with Hollywood celebrities.Mars Attacks! is essentially a throwback to 1950s drive-in sci-fi cheesiness, and it lives up to that legacy. Just don't go expecting that mid-'90s CGI to hold up all that well in today's climate. However, I imagine that also gives it a kind of throwback charm in itself. Wicked humor, alien gore and funny sfx. Loved it !

Review title: A victim of its own success
Review_body: The film is a faithful reconstruction of the a cheesy alien invasion flicks of the 1950's. It captures the tenor and humor of the trading cards it is based on. It is sardonic, bizarre and campy. It is entertaining on that level. But the script, effects are too good at re-creating the vibe of the material it is parodying...the film is too good-as in it is made by professionals-to be authentically psychotronic; it is not sublimely awful in the way say Robot Monster is. A bolder film would have used an unknown cast and presented a less slick film.The acting lacks the stiffness of the psychotronic films; moreover the script is too competent and coherent to create the deeper awfulness the films seems to be aiming for. Even the Deus Ex Machina has a partial set-up because the writing is competent. The resulting film is fun and funny in that it recreates this stuff...but its recreation is shallow and the studio didn't allow for a truly daring vision. I like this but the Lost Skeleton of Cadavra films are far more compelling at this sort of parody, homage.

Mars Attacks! is the kind of film you expect to watch only once and then abandon forever, since the plot sounds like a stupid update of some B-movie from the '50s (perhaps Ed Wood's Plan 9 from Outer Space, considering Tim Burton's previous film was about said director). But somehow, you end up liking it, for, apparently, no reason at all, at least there's no rational explanation, and you keep enjoying it, as the years (and viewings) go by...The story is very simple, and quite risible too: Martians invade the planet and people start running in panic, while the President of the United States (Jack Nicholson) tries to find a solution to the problem. Everything's about to turn into a very funny mess...As stupid as it might sound, the film actually rocks, perhaps because Tim Burton has understood he's not meant to treat the movie seriously, and therefore he gives us a wonderful parody of his key theme (the outcast's struggle against the people who don't understand him). There are only three typical burtonian things in Mars Attacks!: the superb main titles sequence, Danny Elfman's grandiose music and a couple of actors. That's actually what's also great about this movie: thespians who normally tackle serious, complex roles, have a hell of a time playing some grotesque, extremely hilarious individuals. These are not the roles we usually associate Nicholson, Danny DeVito, Glenn Close and Annette Bening with (oh, I almost forgot the priceless dorky scientist played by Pierce Brosnan). There are few ordinary people in the film, most notably Natalie Portman's First Daughter and Sylvia Sidney's half-senile Grandma, a truly great comedic creation.Not the usual Burton flick, but still worth your time.

(Flash Review)This is an amusing and odd little movie with a massive cast of A-listers. As the title implies, aliens storm Earth with oodles of spaceships. The United States with Nicholson as president try to welcome them as friends but are quickly and brazenly attacked by the happy and colorful styled aliens. The rest of the movie is everyone trying to avoid being zapped by their deadly ray guns while trying to find a way to halt their invasion. There is light comedy interwoven as you wait to see which Hollywood star will be zapped next. The special effects, weapons and sound effects are reminiscent to the 50s Martian movies and are well-done. The funniest moment for me was when the military fires a nuke at them, some alien device sucks up the explosion and then an alien smokes the captured nuclear explosion matter with a pipe! Overall, this was fairly thin but strangely amusing.
If you love 50's sci-fi then this is the movie for you. Burton's humor is dark and funny. Natalie Portman replaces Winona Ryder in her usual dark roles in Burton films. Jack Nicholson is the mvp.

It's often said of a film that it's not as good as the book it is based upon. Here's a movie not as good as the bubble-gum cards it was based upon.Way back in the 1960s when director Tim Burton was a boy, Topps Chewing Gum put out these cards depicting a cartoonish Martian invasion of Earth, based loosely on "War Of The Worlds." Explosions, death, fire, monsters, and a glint of goonish humor, it was all a growing boy could want. Years later, his career as Hollywood's most visionary director underway, Burton decided to make a film celebrating those cards."Mars Attacks!" is a hodgepodge of loosely-knit moments with a cast that is way too large to support its slender thread of a story. It's supposed to be thrilling and funny, but it's neither. Instead, you have a succession of blind-alley bits with name actors embarrassing themselves, including Jack Nicholson twice as the president and as a gambler.Pointlessness rules. "Do Martians have two sexes, like we do?" asks an androgynous reporter at a press conference. Rod Steiger as a general is shrunk and stepped on. Boy scouts are squashed by the Washington Monument when the Martians knock it down. Tom Jones is singing "It's Not Unusual" on stage when he is suddenly joined by a trio of Martians.These are set up as punchlines, but there's nothing to punch here but piffle. There's some uniqueness to the Martians themselves, presented in early computer graphic imagery to resemble the day-glo plastic look of the bubble-gum-card Martians of Burton's youth. Jim Brown and Pam Grier offer some humor and sympathy as separated parents trying to save themselves and their two sons, and you wish they were around longer.Everything else, especially a pathetic subplot involving a grievously sick-looking Sylvia Sidney and a puberty-challenged Lukas Haas who discover the Martians' Achilles heel, seems to have been pulled from Stephen King's wastebasket. What was Danny DeVito's purpose in the film? He has fifth billing, and maybe five lines, all of which sound improvised and not in a good way. Annette Bening is a New Age alcoholic who talks like Marilyn Monroe and runs from the invaders, the best performance but one sadly undernourished by dramatic or comic purpose.Watching this film, I thought of "1941," another comedy spectacle that puts glitz over humor. Except this time there's not even a funny speech like Dan Aykroyd's "Was that Mickey Mouse I saw marching into Poland?" bit to latch onto, just a series of sloppy non sequiturs by actors paying Burton back for having once put them in better films. The script is lame, and like "1941" it's hard to imagine so many professional film people letting this one go through their hands without demanding a major rewrite. As with "1941," the idea is if you have a hot director with a unique visionary style, why not trust him to pull it all together?"Mars Attacks!" is the answer. It's a sad little splat of a film, an early demonstration of CGI that also demonstrates how limited CGI as a tool can be. Burton is so much better when he lets the story dictate special effects, rather than the other way around.

Mars Attacks! is a very funny and sometimes misunderstood film. This is Tim Burton's big budgeted, ensemble A list cast satirical comedy that is a homage to 50's era B movie science fiction. The film is very stylized and very specific to the old school alien invasion movies. This is totally tongue in cheek and campy. This kind of parody and humor, you either get or you don't. I personally enjoy the movie and yes , the movie is ridiculous. But, that is the point and Mars Attacks delivers and is totally over the top and very funny.

Review title: A very amusing game of 40 little indians.
Review_body: stars: Jack Nicholson, Lukas Haas, Pierce Brosnan, Annette Benning, Sarah Jessica Parker, Jim Brown, Sylvia Sydney, Martin Short, Glenn Close, Tom Jones, Rod Steiger, Michael J. Fox, Pam Grier, Natalie Portman, O-Lan Jones, Joe Don Baker, Ray J, Brandon Hammond, Jack Black, Brian Haley, Paul Winfield, Danny Devito, Lisa Marie, Christina Applegate, Janice Rivera and others.This movie is very amusing. It's a spoof of those old cheesy sci-fi alien movies. It's surprisingly slow paced and quiet for a shoot em up alien movie. Instead of driven by the aliens (which t is partially), it is mostly character driven. This film has such a big, talented cast and the aliens are good looking and quite amusing. I'm sure the writers and director Tim Burton got a kick out of finding out different ways to kill most of these actors off.SPOILER: In order of their death: Paul Winfield, Jack Black, Michael J. Fox, Martin Short, Glenn Close, Jack Nicholson (as the hotel owner), Christina Applegate, O-Lan Jones, Joe Don Baker, Danny Devito, Brian Haley, Rod Steiger, Jack Nicholson (as the president), Pierce Brosnan and Sarah Jessica Parker.So, I do recommend this for the for the amusing aliens and the non-stop celebrity performances.my rating: 7/10. 107 mins. PG-13 for violence, some language and a sex scene.

Tim Burton's entire life seems to be one big camp film, and this movie obviously brought some of his poorly wired thoughts to the forefront. Sometimes, funny, sometimes dull, and often times ridiculous, Mars Attacks! breaths life into a film which appears to have none. But then again, why argue over such trivialities? The casting was perfect, with Jack Nicholson doing a parody of himself, being over the top and too macho for the role. While the flow of the film seemed rigid and forced, the intent was simply meant to make fun of old-time sci-fi films. Good job on the parodying, but a rather average job on making all of these elements work succinctly.

No one likes and respects Tim Burton more than I do, but I draw the line at this movie.  I understand what it was supposed to have been, but it didn't do it.  See "Invaders from Mars" or "Strange Invaders" for the same story done correctly.  I do thank him for giving Sylvia Sidney another job, tho. And anyone who puts Tom Jones and Jim Brown in his movie cannot be all bad!

If Independence Day (also 1996) updated the classic alien invasion movie of the 50s and 60s, Mars Attacks! spoofed it to the hilt. Here producer-director Tim Burton once again stands up for his B-movie-loving corner of the 90s fad for tongue-in-cheek nostalgia.Burton has never been an exceptional visual director, but he has a certain knack at coming up with bizarre looking shots, such as one of Jack Nicholson's head a dot between the shoulders of the assembled press. He also clearly knows a few cinema-savvy tricks at handling the ensemble cast. Look at the first shot of Natalie Portman – she's just a background figure in this scene, but it opens with a shot of her, Glenn Close's scarf flying across the frame. This helps us remember her even though she's not really very active in this part of the movie.That aforementioned ensemble cast is perhaps the best thing about Mars Attacks! OK, no-one here does anything exactly exceptional, but every one has their place in the spirit of the thing. There are too many to mention them all, but special attention must go to the following: Leading lady of the 30s Sylvia Sidney as a lovable and non-stereotyped grandma; Rod Steiger, it seems the taking his role seriously as generally did, which works because it makes him look appropriately pompous amidst everything else; Danny De Vito, a bit over-the-top but showing great comic timing and exuberant use of his small frame; and Pam Grier, making a big impression in a small amount of screen time.Whereas most comedies would have some kind of action, romance or human story, Mars Attacks! is just pure and farcical spoof. It doesn't really have much point beyond that. It seems to make up for its lack of grand plan by simply being as constantly silly as possible. And on this basis it works well enough. Rather than the carefully-planned structure of a conventional screenplay, this one simply bounces from one madcap idea to the next like a series of Monty Python sketches, a dozen or so plot-holes swept under the carpet. It's a minor movie really by any consideration, but it's good fun for its 100 minutes.

Review title: Fun Parody with Bigger Social Commentary
Review_body: This film was one that I watched a lot growing up. I remember it hitting the movie channels and it is just so quirky, that myself and I would watch it all the time. She ended up getting it on VHS, which got a lot of use as well. I really enjoyed it as a child, but it wasn't until I got older that I really started to understand how deep this film is. The synopsis is Earth is invaded by Martians with unbeatable weapons and a cruel sense of humor.It then begins showing us a farm house. A man on a tractor asks an Asian man if he is cooking up a feast. The Asian man tells him he is not, but then we see a herd of cows run by that are on fire. We then see a spaceship as it flies away. We then see that this spaceship is from Mars. More of them come and have a blockade around Earth.We then meet that the president of the United States James Dale (Jack Nicholson). His press secretary is played is Jerry Ross (Martin Short). He has two military officers in the oval office as well General Decker (Rod Steiger) and General Casey (Paul Winfield). Jerry wants to go to the press and just wants to know if they should when they should go on. General Decker on the other hand wants to keep this private and get ready for war. President Dale wants to gather more information first, but he wants to go with Jerry's plan to inform the nation.Some of the other people we follow are President Dale's wife Marsha (Glenn Close), who is of course the first lady. They have a daughter Taffy (Natalie Portman). Also in Washington D.C. is Louise Williams (Pam Grier). She's a bus driver that is divorced, trying to raise two boys who are handful. They're named Cedric (Ray J) and Neville (Brandon Hammond) and currently they're giving their mother a headache by playing hooky from school. The ex-husband is Bryon (Jim Brown), who is a former heavyweight boxing champion. He currently lives in Las Vegas and working as a greeter at a casino. He is trying to work things out with Louise with a plan of a visiting soon.Also in Las Vegas is Art Land (also Nicholson) whose a shady businessman trying to open up a new hotel. He is married to Barbara (Annette Bening).In between them is a family that lives in the middle of nowhere in the Midwest. There is Richie Norris (Lukas Haas). His older brother is Billy Glenn (Jack Black) who is in the military. Their father is Joe Don Baker and mother is O-Lan Jones. They also have a grandmother that lives in a nursing home named Florence (Sylvia Sidney). She is a little bit out of it though and calls everyone Billy. Sharona (Christina Applegate) is dating Billy Glenn as well.The final people to introduce are a couple of reporters who live together. Nathalie Lake (Sarah Jessica Parker) is one of them and does fashion pieces mostly for her station, but she works for a more popular channel. Jason Stone (Michael J. Fox) works for a rival company, GNN, and they seem to be constantly coming in second place.President Dale cuts in to let everyone know about the Martians coming to Earth. He tells them that they'll be contact and not to panic. Soon after, Professor Donald Kessler (Pierce Brosnan) goes on Nathalie's show and it is interrupted by the aliens. Their message is translated to want to meet up. General Casey is given command and everyone thinks it's going smoothly until the aliens attack. President Dale is clinging to the notion that it was just a misunderstanding or is Mars here to conquer Earth?Something that I alluded to earlier was that I never really picked up how deep this parody actually goes. The first thing that I realized was this is kind of a take on War of the Worlds while also being based off a trading card series back in the day. We really are getting these aliens coming to Earth, unprovoked and trying to wipe us out. There is a hilarious update to what can kill these aliens though for sure.It is after this viewing that I realized how much deeper this story of the film goes to and is extremely socially relevant now. President Dale seems like a good president, but he is really just worried about doing the right thing to get re-elected. Jerry just really wants to be transparent with the people as possible, which is ironic as he frequents hookers. General Decker is your typical Right wing, as he just wants to go to war and kill, then you have General Casey who is timid and completely the opposite. Professor Kessler really just doesn't want to be wrong as he is a man of science. General Decker of course doesn't want to listen to him either. The crazy thing is though, the film is showing that all of these people are wrong in what they want to do and it causes the deaths of a ton of people!I also couldn't miss the parallels here to coming to America or other places that were colonized. Something that confuses me is the first message that is sent, I almost feel like was a declaration of war and our machine misinterpreted it. It is an interesting assumption that we can defeat these aliens so easily if it was an invasion, which was much like what happened during colonization to the indigenous people.All of this is wrapped in an outrageous comedy. There were parts that I know were coming that still really make me laugh. I like the idea that these aliens have been coming to Earth and have been investigating things. It is fun seeing them experiment to learn more and some of things that happen are just great.With that said, the pacing of this film is really good. It doesn't waste any time from the beginning to get right into it. There is such a big cast to introduce, but I think it does a great job at making it seem natural and quite seamless. The invasion happens pretty soon after that and that gets just progressively worse. I like how it ends and what is used here to fight them off, it still cracks me up to this day. It is an interesting parallel for sure what was used in War of the Worlds.I've already touched on it, but the acting in this film is great. I can give credit to everyone, but I'll do my best. Nicholson is hilarious and playing two quite different roles. It is after a film like this you really see his range and what he can do. Close is solid as his vapid wife. Bening is interesting as she is a new age hippie. She is also one of the first to realize that these aliens aren't friendly and sticks to this. Brosnan is solid as is DeVito. Short, Steiger and Winfield all make for a interesting trio who don't always see eye to eye. Brown, Grier, Parker, Fox, Haas, Portman and the rest definitely round out the film for what is needed and I don't think there's a bad performance if I'm honest.Something I've been waiting to cover would be the effects of the film. Coming in, you really know this is a CGI fest. What I'm surprised by though, is that most of it is really good. I'm not saying all of it, as there are times that I thought that it doesn't look good or hold up, but for the most part though, it is on point. The Martians, their weapons and vehicles are all CGI as well as the attacks they do. It looks pretty solid though actually. The film is shot very well also.I couldn't end this without talking about the soundtrack of the film. I think that it does a really good job at sounding like a 1950's sci-fi for a good stretch, which is another thing that it is parodying. There is a song that is pretty hilarious that you will know exactly what I'm talking about if you've seen this or end up watching this. I also liked how the aliens sound when they talk as well. This all just fit the film for me.Now with that said, this film is one that I really enjoyed growing up. It wasn't until I got older that I really understood how deep this film really is. It does poke fun at not only War of the Worlds, 50's sci-fi films, but it also looks at political and social ideas from the past and present as well. It is paced in a way that it moves fast and never gets boring. The acting definitely helps there and the CGI surprisingly holds up. The soundtrack definitely fits for what is needed and the aliens talking are hilarious. Now being that this is part comedy, that prevents me from giving this a higher rating, but I don't know if you can present how this film is in a more serious way without being a remake. I definitely think this is good and should be given a viewing as it is fun.

I'd LIKE to be kind, if only because of the stop-motion Martians.  Tim Burton may be the only director in the world, now that Stanley Kubrick is dead, who isn't hopelessly infatuated with computer-generated effects.  He deserves our respect.  And indeed, his Martians are gorgeous: their sneaky movements, their ludicrous ack-acking language, their big greebly eyes...That's as kind as I'm going to get, because by gawd, this movie stinks.  I never believed reports on how bad it was until now.  Interplanetary war! How can anyone take such a sure-fire theme and crash it into the ground?By shutting down the engines and letting gravity take its course, that's how.  Burton has a central premise he does nothing with.  The opening scenes on Earth aren't one bit funny.  The rhythm is all wrong for comedy.  Look at the way his poor actors have to deliver lines that might possibly, in vastly different circumstances, have been amusing, only to be swallowed up by deadly silence - not that the silence ever lasts long enough to be amusing in its own right.  And yet the characters don't grab us when we take them straight, either.  Was it meant to be parody?  If so I can't help thinking of another such parody: 1980's "Airplane!" (released as "Flying High" in Australia).  That film exalted in its ability to manipulate - it played EVERYTHING for cheap laughs, and yet somehow one felt keenly for the caricature of a hero at its heart.  Maybe it's because caricatures at least have sharp outlines.  The terrestrial characters in "Mars Attacks" are just lumps of dough.Elfman's musical score, sad to say, makes a bad thing worse.  I know he's done fine work in the past - "Batman" and "The Nightmare Before Christmas", for instance - but here he just doesn't seem to have a clue.  Never have I come across a score that covered so much of the action while doing so little for it.  Not that I really blame Elfman.  Forced to comment musically on scenes which go nowhere, what is he supposed to say?

Mars Attacks is the kind of movie you watch repeatedly thinking, "That's a funny idea...." without ever actually laughing. It shows up frequently on late-night t.v. where I have now given it several 2nd chances; always with a pained expression on my face, while my mind devises elaborate ways to casue Tim Burton pain. The movie needs a lighter touch (which Burton has at this point proved himself incapable of) and it's airhead humor & plotpoints are undermined by the starpower delivery. That goes double for the budget. The "realism" of CGI doesn't help an idea as silly as this one. I don't need to believe the martians have the correct radiosity, shadow depth, animation speed etc. to have a laugh, and the production design is pretty much ruined by the digital insertions (...purposely OR obliviously crappy). It would take a cast of nobodies to put this thing over. Watching a cast of overqualified stars trying way too hard to be funny, with a script and a director who can't help them, is remarkably unsatisfying.I think I laughed twice, the "friendly Martian" translations while they incinerate people and the ability of "Ack ack ack" to mean just about anything.This movie is atrocious. For the record I started out loving Tim Burton movies and he alone wore out his welcome. His puerile mind hasn't moved an inch in twenty years. His Batman movies now look cheap, lurid and stupid. His movies reflect the emotional development of a five-year old. (Yes, including the execrable Big Fish) He wouldn't know a finished script if it bit him on the ass. I doubt the guy can even tell a joke.

When I first saw this shortly after it was released I I wondered why critics and moviegoers were whining about it so much.It harkens back to the cheesy 50s space invaders/Cold War movies with their low-rent special effects and gung-ho military response. Except now we get to enjoy it in garish technicolor and 90s spooferama.I understand there was a Mars Attacks set of trading cards issued by Topps in 1962. That's before my time but if you look them up online you'll get the idea what inspired the look of this movie.There are so many recognizable faces having a blast it's pointless to list them all. My favorite is Sylvia Sidney, in her last big-screen credit.Like everyone else who loves this movie, I have my favorite scenes:1. Hippies releasing the dove, only to see the Martians vaporize it with a ray gun.2. President Nicholson giving his speech in the war room about 2 out of 3 branches of the federal government still being operational, so Americans don't have to worry about garbage collection. That scene might have played like satire at the time, but in a year when we have Gramma Killer Cuomo on TV every day announcing lockdowns and bloviating about his own leadership skills, it's practically a documentary.3. Lawn bowling at Easter Island.It is depressing to consider its competition in 1996 - the execrable, self-serious, flag-waving Independence Day - made about a billion dollar while this tanked at the box office. I mean, come on, Jim Brown or Will Smith as the bl@ck hero? A real man or a smug twerp?My theory is that low IQ American moviegoers want movies to reflect their paranoid fantasies about being the rulers of the world. Independence Day fed that. Mars Attacks subverts it in every scene.

Good watch, could watch again, but it's hard to honestly recommend.This is one of those movies that is good because it is bad, whether or not that is done on purpose, for the purposes of parody. Otherwise it's just a good old jump in "The Way Back Machine" to see a litany of cameos or cheap parts by almost anyone who was famous in the mid-1990s. Though I do feel like most of the actors I liked were essentially wasted, but it is possible that was by design so the Martians could keep the focus for the majority of the movie.Rethinking on the movie almost makes me want a modernization, it has so many little quirks and nuances that really brings it to a special experience. Even if you think it looks terrible, throw this on your queque and slot it in for a Bad Movie Night.

Review title: A Cult Classic That's Fun To Watch
Review_body: At first, I was a bit hesitant in watching Tim Burton's "Mars! Attacks" fearing that it'll be another box office failure like his other project, "Ed Wood". I didn't like the idea that he was letting money burn in front of him. When he made "Ed Wood", it had a multi-million budget and yet it sadly lost a lot on opening day. "Mars Attacks!" unfortunately met the same fate as well. It cost $80 million to make and failed its expectency to gross $120 million on its opening night. Well when you get a macabre twisted-minded director Tim Burton, you have to expect the unexpected. Even though it didn't fare well at the box office, in later years it developed into a cult classic with a nice blend of dark humour, nihilistic satire, and an exciting alein invasion story that pays homage to the old 1950's sci-fi films. Unlike the other alien invasion film "Independence Day", this one is strictly parody and where suspending your disbelief is mandatory."Mars Attacks!" commences when a herd of cattle in flames lands in a small American town and then a flying saucer is captured with the question if whether or not they're peaceful visitors, or are they here with evil intentions? After landing in a Nevada desert, the Martians are acquainted by President James Dale (Jack Nicholson) and other nearby civilians, but soon after we discover that the alien creature's real intentions are to cause chaos, destruction and to end humanity. At first the President thinks it's all a bit of miscommunication and that the Alien Ambassador goes out of his way in his language by saying "We come in peace". However like we expected all along that was all just a rouse and next thing you know, the creatures start zapping everything and everyone even the President himself gets burned to a crisp.The madness doesn't end there. The film take great liberties with a side dish of unapologies about poking fun at those science-fiction films that dominated the theatres in the 1940's and 1950's with his own sick twists to it. The idea for the movie was based off of the "Mars Attacks!" Topp's cards that were abolished in the 1950's the film depends on slapstick humour, witty dialogue, surreal insanity, special effects and total annihilation. Many cast members get destroyed in this movie, but the funny thing is the various ways they meet their fate which takes a more cartoonish approach as opposed to the more gritty fate we see in other films of this particular genre. You'll be gasping in awe over Jason Stone (Michael J. Fox) as he reaches for 's hand. Or the eye-soring moment when a dog's head is transferred over Nathalie Lake's (Sarah Jessica Parker) body. The whole atmosphere of the movie is like something taken out of a comic-book.The cast choices were excellent like I had anticipated. Aside from playing a level-headed President, Nicholson was also amazing in another role as an opportunistic Vegas businessman, Art Land. Glenn Close was wonderful as as neurotic First Lady Marsha Dale. Annette Bening is amazing as spiritual hippie Barbara Land who's fixated on meeting the Martians. Danny DeVito shows his screen charisma as the Rude Gambler who tries to strike a deal with the aliens. Jim Brown turns in a reamakable performance as boxer Byron Williams who wants to take on the aliens. Fox and Parker were excellent as determined reporters. Lisa Marie was memorable as a gaunt looking alien who goes incognito to woo Press Secretary Jerry Ross (Martin Short). The real scene stealer is from Sylvia Sidney as elderly woman Florence Norris who becomes the unsung hero of the day.The creature design of the aliens are quite impressive. They are green in complexion with skeletal bodies and inflated brains and have more advanced weaponry making humans the underdogs in their hostile takeover. They zap, destroy and kill, while having fun in the process. Their dialogue is incoherent and the only thing that comes out of their mouths are "Ack! Ack! Ack!"If there is any weakness it would be that the early scenes with the aliens communicating starts to wear thin very quickly. In addition to that all that "ack, ack" stuff doesn't make them convince the audience that they are more superior to humans in terms of language. But once the carnage takes off, it goes by in a breeze. There are plenty of memorable quotes that will linger in my mind for a long time like when brainy child Richie Norris (Lukas Haas) tries to inerpret the alien's sign language, he claims he's giving the international sign of the donut. I also enjoyed President Dale's cheesy speech about "why can't we all just get along"? Even singing legend Tom Jones confronting the aliens was funny just by the surrealism the whole movie contains.Sure it's not one of Tim Burton's best film, but the spoofs and homage it's based on exceeds anything we have seen from other outrageous films that are equally daring like "Beetlejuice" and "Batman". Burton knew he wasn't getting his money back on this movie, but he was having fun making this movie and in the end that's all that really matters.

Review title: Not for people who take Sci-Fi very serious (like for example Trekkie's)
Review_body: Mars Attacks probably has the same problem many other of Tim Burton's movies encounter. I guess many people don't really like it because they don't fully understand it. They take it all a bit too serious, while that's exactly something you shouldn't do with his movies. Personally I'm a fan of his work and I love the way he combines fantasy with comedy in this movie. Yes, it looks a bit like a spoof that has taken over the style of fifties movies and you definitely can't say this is a very subtle comedy, but it certainly works for me. It shows how the Martians come to Earth and first seem to be peaceful. But they aren't, in reality all they want is to conquer humanity and to claim the world as theirs.What you'll see is a president who can't even keep his family under control, but who still is convinced he's the most powerful man on earth, martians who can't stand the music of some crooner who's name I don't know (let's call him yodeling Zeke), a war loving general who thinks nuclear weapons are the answer to everything, a scientific adviser who is certain that the attack of the Martians is based on a misunderstanding (that must be the reason, because such a highly developed and intelligent culture can't be violent),... In fact, this movie was really entertaining, but shouldn't be taken too serious, even though this movie isn't even that far from the truth. Of course it magnifies everything at least 100 times, but there is some form of truth to be found in it. And I loved the way the Aliens looked like. Have you ever seen an Alien? No? Me neither, but does that mean we can't laugh with it? I don't see why not. I've seen many pictures of Aliens, but these certainly were the best and the funniest. However, if you think Sci-Fi is something that shouldn't be messed with, than I guess you better leave this movie alone, because you'll be very disappointed by it. On the other hand, if you are in for a good laugh, than I certainly recommend this movie. I give it a 7.5/10

AAK AAK even though mars attacks! Is outdated its still funny. The aliens are freaky looking and there is some good actors in this although I didn't like Jack Nicholson as the drunk cowboy. A remake would be cool.

Review title: Not the satire it wants to be.
Review_body: Tim Burton's Mars Attacks! is a homage to 1950s sci-fi that fits in with the ensemble disaster films of the 1990s. I've always been a big fan of Tim Burton, his Big Fish was my first taste of what cinema could be, but even though this film was during the peak of his power, it's still a big let down. It has an insanely huge cast of talent with Jack Nicholson (in two roles), Glenn Close, Natalie Portman, Annette Bening, Michael J. Fox, Danny DeVito, Rod Steiger and many more, all given stock desires and conflicts with none particularly focused on and few resolved. The cast was why I watched it as well as the fact that it's on my watchlist from university in regards to music in film so it was worth watching in some regard but despite my low expectations it was still quite a disappointment.The first half is significantly better than the eye-rolling second, even though not much plot development is made. It's spent slowly setting up all the characters and humanity's reaction to martians. It's quite amusing at times, but never laugh out loud, feeling like it's completely comprised of the quirky side characters of Burton's other films and lacking the protagonist to root for. It's all pretty half decent for what it is, but unfortunately it has horrible and flat special effects which it relies on more than anything. Maybe it was the best of its kind at the time (though Independence Day in the same year was far superior), this is very primitive and most of the time it doesn't look like it belongs in the film's reality. Even some of the non-CGI effects are very poor. Perhaps this was more than Burton could handle or producers intervened, but it doesn't work and he should've tried for a stop motion or puppet effect.It does have some good elements. Danny Elfman's creative score is the biggest part of the homage to the 1950s sci-fi and that music plays a big theme in the story. While the score features the theremin prominently as the alien's signature sound, calling back to The Day The Earth Stood Still, it is the in film pseudo-country music that defeats the aliens. This suggests the idea, regarding pop culture, of what is now considered ordinary, the eeriness of the theremin over the country. However, contrivances in the script are very bothersome and ruin most of its execution. There's little sense of escalation from the first half to the second. It's the cringeworthy comedic and hokey moments in the second half that completely ruin the film and quickly wears out its welcome becoming one awful gag after the other that's doesn't feel like the satire it wants to be. A very weak effort for Burton.4/10

Review title: Humorous intent marred by overdone brutality
Review_body: Humorous parody of vintage '50's sci-fi movies, utilizing many of the plot devices so popular in that era. Many well known celebs joined in the fun for this clever satire, and most of them play devious, plotting, selfish, evil characters who you don't mind seeing getting vaporized on the business end of a ray gun blast. If the film had confined the violence to these degenerates, this ingenious parody would have been better off, but the wanton carnage is extended to innocents, the movie's one major weakness. Two cities, representing nests of human debris, Las Vegas and Washington DC, are the main targets for the Martian Creatures. The design of the invaders is delightfully absurd yet scary at the same time. Their motives are shown to be just as sinister as the Earthlings they are exterminating. They grin like idiots and chatter their only sentence in English, "We are your friends" as they annihilate victims with reckless abandon. Funny movie; could have been better if the violence had been limited to just the characters who had it coming.

Review title: Excellent cast wasted--but I hope they had fun
Review_body: BEWARE OF SPOILERSI watched this ridiculous scfi spoof of aliens in flying saucers invading earth starring Jack Nicholson, Annette Bening, Sarah Jessica Parker, Glenn Close, football's Jim Brown and even little Natalie Portman on Comcast's On Demand. It waswell, as bad as the movies it was spoofing. Yet I watched the whole thing because I wondered what the gimmick would be that killed off the Martians. Earth viruses or bacteria a la "The War of the Worlds"? Nuclear weapons? The milk of human kindness? Divine love? The cross of Christianity or the crescent of Islam? No DEVASTATING SPOILER TO COME!!!! BEWARE!!!!----->no, it was Country and Western music. I shuck you not.I am hereby revealing the ending and the funny, ha, ha gimmick as a public service so that you will not be seduced into watching this and thereby wasting what precious time you have left when you could be otherwise gainfully employed, say by playing along on the Game Network Channel or going to the "Going Out of Business" sales at Linens and Things or Circuit City or listening to Rush Limbaugh on the radio or Howard Stern, or even reading your spam emails.Yes, I did try to see the High Camp and appreciate the wonderful cast and realize that this a comedy and that I should chill out, have a little fun, laugh a little and don't be so High Brow. But I failed. Miserably. But one thing I did get out of this picture it is the answer to the trivia question: what was the worse movie that Jack Nicholson ever played in? That would be the same as the answer to the question What was the worse movie that Annette Bening ever played in?"Mars Bars Attack" might have been better. Chocolate bars with guns a-blazing coming out of the flying saucers--now that might have been funny. Or not. And, by the way, everybody knows that in an alien movie with luscious alien babes, you never, but never, but never kiss her. But no, Martin Short has never seen an alien movie with luscious alien babes in it and so he tries a little tongue action with Lisa Marie and boy did he ever get burned! Ha, ha, ha.(Note: Over 500 of my movie reviews are now available in my book "Cut to the Chaise Lounge or I Can't Believe I Swallowed the Remote!" Get it at Amazon!)

Review title: Perhaps that's why I don't like it, I can't stand John Waters!
Review_body: One reviewer compared this film to the style of John Waters. Aha! mystery solved! Now I know why I see so much I dislike in the movie.I had only seen two Waters films at the time of writing, "Serial Mom" (just about passable) and "Cry-baby" (awful) and fail to see why so many people love him. He seems like the Howard Stern (for those of you who don't know: American 'shock-jock') of modern American film, and resorting to cheap publicity shots like having someone eat dog feces, as he did in one film, fails to hide the fact that you're an incompetent film maker.Still, this is a comment on "Mars Attacks!", far and away Burton's weakest film. No, I didn't pop it in the VCR expecting a serious commentary on alien invasion, the publicity for the film should give you an idea of the kind of tone that the film adopts. What I did expect were some smart gags and an intelligent pastiche of '50's sci-fi. What I actually got was several big-name stars besmirching their previous work by reading lines from a script that didn't possess one solitary zinger...(SPOILER.)There was one great sight gag (where Michael J. Fox tries to grab the dog and the next shot shows just his hand) and that was it. Maybe I haven't seen enough cheesy sci-fi to appreciate it, but to my mind the best spoofs are the ones that are still funny even if you haven't seen what they are parodying ("Airplane!" is a classic example, hilarious to me even though I haven't seen any of the "Airport" series which I believe was the inspiration)Burton's over-reliance on cross-reference to generate the laughs just points to serious script deficiencies, in my opinion. Lack of a faintly original take on the films he supposedly loves kills the movie. A shame, because I had high hopes for this before I watched it, and I like all of Tim Burton's other work. Chalk this one down to experience and go watch "Beetlejuice"!

Mars Attacks sounds terrific on paper. A tongue in cheek alien attack film featuring a mega-cast of the past, present and futurely famous. Unfortunately most of them far better actors than this material deserves When the aliens – *AHEM* Martian-Americans – arrive, it is assumed that they must be intelligent beings who seek to share knowledge, and the President of the USA (Jack Nicholson) delightedly informs his nation of the breakthrough in inter-species relations.The fact that the Martians are 3 ½ foot tall and look like a skull with a massive exposed brain enclosed in a clear dome isn't at all offputting.The fact that they converse in a loud obnoxious "ACK. ACK. ACK." doesn't bother anyone.The fact that they kill the US Army General sent to formally welcome them, then lay waste to hundreds of onlookers desperate to be part of first contact is written off as a misunderstanding.Once the Martians take out an entire body of government, then set to eradicating the entire population, that fact becomes a little harder to swallow.But none of that should surprise the viewer of course, after all it is called 'Mars Attacks', not 'Mars drops in to say Hi'.The actual plot line is essentially irrelevant, which is why it matter not one iota that they gave it away in the title. What is supposed to matter is that Tim Burton has amassed a cadre of talent to act dumbfounded, outraged and perturbed at appropriate times in a film inspired by a set of bubblegum cards.Burton gleefully ignores standard cinema protocol and builds hero moments only to have the hero killed at the exact wrong point. He sets up scenes where love is about to find a way – then chuckles to himself when it doesn't.The film plays no favourites and obeys no conventions, the President of the US is no safer than singer Tom Jones, being Jack Nicholson doesn't make you any different from being Jack Black (in one of his first films – he's almost skinny here!).Meanwhile the Martians poke, prod and test their human captives, again with allegedly hilarious results, but might I say that Sarah Jessica Parker actually looks new and improved sporting a dog's head? My main gripe is this: I know that this is all delightfully silly and deliberately juvenile stuff, but that doesn't make it entertaining or somehow more worthy of merit. The fact that Burton set out to make a dumb film shouldn't be seen as a positive, if anything he should be flogged for wasting his considerable talents on this indulgent crap.I know that many viewers with 'mainstream' tastes see Mars Attacks as acceptable as they want to embrace and enjoy something silly, and feel they can only do so if said film is made by a man universally acknowledged as an 'eccentric genius'.I also know that many cinema aficionados and Burton acolytes see Mars Attacks as Tim Burton thumbing his nose to those same mainstream lemmings.But know this. Regardless of who made Mars Attacks, who starred in it and why it was made; it is a laugh free, amateurish snoozefest, with a severe docking in score for the persistent stream of trite and misguided jokes and alleged sightgags and less entertainment value than a Saturday morning cartoon.If Tim Burton wants to be all ironic and indulgent, let him do it on his own time. On behalf of Earth, I apologise to any extra-terrestrial beings who think we humans see this as 'entertainment'.Final Rating – 4.5 / 10. I dislike Mars Attacks more for what it is supposed to be than what it is. But with the cast, the budget and the talent behind the scenes, this should have been so much more than a childish and plain stupid vanity project.I'd rather watch Battle: Los Angeles 5 times in a row – with the sound way up – than sit through this again.
Comedy masterpiece of its time that continues to make people laugh even today. This film represents how Burton is a genius even when he breaks away from the style that made him famous.

I'm not a fan of Tim Burton, and I didn't even like this movie first time around.  But I really enjoyed it on repeat viewings.  Sick/comical portrayal of Martian landings on earth.  Things get a little gruesome, but the celebrity cast plays the script to the hilt, and everyone seems to be having a good time.

Review title: Disappointing as a whole -- but some nice moments to help.
Review_body: "This is a notch for my Administration." "This looks like a good photo-op for me, should I be down there?"These two lines sets what makes Mars Attacks tolerable for me.With all the big names, and the marketing behind this to be a "blockbuster", I think this film was given more credit than what it deserved to be -- and that was a funny film based on 50's martian movies.I laugh at this film more NOW than I did then..because I was caught up in the hype that never should have happened..and the stars that never shoulda been in it..or the script that had way too much put into it.Hindsight is 20/20 and the reason I find this movie so funny now is because it reminds me so much of America's current Bush Administration. The lines coming out of Jack Nicholson's mouth, as he played the President, is funny as all heck.But Jack Nicholson playing the shark..well, that part could have been left on the editing room floor. As well as Annette Benning's Role, but Annette should have played Sarah Jessica Parker's role (and visa versa really...) with a more meatier and more developed script. Martin Short's role had promise and just went the wacky-stupid route which was unfortunate. Michael J. Fox's role was hilarious but very one dimentional which is sad. Pam Grier and Jim Brown were almost lost in this film. Little things like this is what makes the film unbearable at times.But in the here and now.. as I watch the late Rod Steiger role, I find it was a preminition of things to come. It was fabulous. That as well as Jack Black's small role. Paul Winfield and his role is in this mix as well, when looking at his roll  with what is going on today..you can't help but laugh at all of this and then wonder..oh my goodness!I had a problem with the Martians...I dunno. I kinda wish they were more like the Kanamits from the old Twilight Zone's favorite, "To Serve Man". Or maybe something more "out there". Ack, Ack....is just how I felt about them even though it was Topps cards these were based on.The ending..yikes!!! Tim Burton's work, which I've always enjoyed, went over the deep end here..and I don't know why. But that doesn't mean this film cannot be enjoyed. You just have to be in a different mindframe to do so.Problems? Well...too many big names, an uneven script, silly looking Martians, horrid ending, but a few nice shots about the workings of Washington, DC, the TV industry...is all you'll get from this.

Review title: Not quite parody not quite homage, Tim Burton's adaptation of the cult classic Topps trading cards has a lot of energy and effort, but not much weight or substance.
Review_body: When a Martian fleet of lying saucers approach the Earth their arrival is witnessed and reacted to by many across the United States. From the upper echelons the American government with President James Dale (Jack Nicholson), science advisor Professor Donald Kessler (Pierce Brosnan) to residents of the flyover states like Richie Norris (Lukas Haas) and his eclectic family of uneducated weirdos (save for his grandmother). The Martians' arrival quickly goes from point of curiosity to unstoppable rampage of destruction as the Martians use their bizarre otherworldly weaponry to destroy humanity.First introduced in 1962 by longstanding trading card company Topps, Mars Attacks! Was a set of 55 individual cards (54 image cards and one checklist) that told the story of an invasion by Mars detailing their attacks utilizing unearthly weapons and genetically enhanced giant bugs until remnants of Earth's armed forces launched a counter attack on Mars resulting in humanity's victory and destruction of Mars. The cards were immensely popular with children but parental, educator, and government outrage at the cards depictions of over the top violence as well as implied sexuality (particularly with card #17 "Beauty and the Beast") lead to the line being removed from the market. Despite launching and ending within in year, the cards are fondly remembered for their beautiful artwork that evoked the covers of pulp novels and took inspiration from the b-rate sci-fi schlock of the day involving flying saucers and giant insects. An initial attempt at a feature film adaptation had been attempted by cult filmmaker Alex Cox in 1985 but never got off the ground. Mars Attacks was brought to the attention of Tim Burton fresh off his critically acclaimed biopic of Ed Wood and saw Mars Attacks as an opportunity to make a big budget Ed Wood type movie with an A-list. The movie was released in December of 1996, 6 months after another alien invasion film, Independence Day, depicted a near identical story except played straight. Mars Attacks ended up underperforming with both critics and audiences and was Burton's first real misfire since his mainstream directing career began with Pee-Wee's Big Adventure (art house numbers of Ed Wood notwithstanding). While Mars Attacks has developed a cult following with people who appreciate its core joke of an A-List cast in service of B-rate material, I myself enjoy individual parts of Mars Attacks, but not enough to wholly recommend it.It'd be pretty pointless to critique Mars Attacks on the basis of plot, narrative, or internal logic because from the outset with its purposefully cheesy soundtrack by Danny Elfman (that is quite good at evoking memories of 1950s sci-fi), to its firmly antiquated designs are inspired by the likes of Earth vs The Flying Saucers or This Island Earth, Mars Attacks wears its goofiness with pride in its writing, production design, and its effects. Technically speaking Mars Attacks gives the perfect feeling of watching a 1950s B-Rate alien invasion film given an A level cast and budget and there's lots of little details sprinkled throughout you can trace back to other films of its ilk such as the Martian leader's video message that is staged almost identically in lighting and presentation to The Amazing Criswell's introduction of Plan 9 From Outer Space or the effect to bring Sarah Jessica Parker and Pierce Brosnan's severed heads to life in homage to something like The Brain that Wouldn't Die.Unfortunately where Mars Attacks stumbles is in its presentation where it lacks the irony to be funny enough to be parody, but it also doesn't have enough substance to serve as a homage with every character written as a puddle deep archetype broadly delivered in the most exaggerated manner possible. Mars Attacks is in the same category of chaotic darkly comic nonsense like Gremlins, Critters, Tremors, or Buckaroo Banzai but it doesn't have the grounding needed to make its premise come to life. While movies like Gremlins and Critters were silly, they also had focus developing central characters so we had a grounding element to bounce off against the oddness and havoc of the Gremlins or Crites. I think Burton didn't really understand the approach to material like this and the film probably would've benefitted from a director like Sam Raimi, Joe Dante, or Ron Underwood of the first Tremors film who were able to create grounded characters in strange scenarios. While Tim Burton is known for his odd eccentric style with stuff like Beetlejuice, Edward Scissorhands, or his Batman films, he's really not capable of creating grounded characters unless it's a situation like the Maitlands from Beetlejuice where their relatively blank slate status as characters was used to contrast against both the undead world and the obnoxious and tacky Deetz family. It's not helped that movie really doesn't get going until about 70 minutes in and actually starts resembling the events on the trading cards with giant robots and destruction of buildings. The opening 70 minutes are meandering and directionless with no one really taking the Martians all that seriously and we basically get variations on the same points over and over again such as Nicholson's calm to a fault President who tries to keep the public calm with FDR-esque fireside chats only to have his comforting words blow up in his face every time. Somewhat funny at first, but less funny upon repeated use.Mars Attacks is the kind of movie you'll either appreciate for its absurdity or scratch your head in confusion. It's high camp on a high budget, but it never goes into full on parody nor does it try to play itself with much weight either hovering somewhere between parody and homage without really satisfying either side of the spectrum. It's pretty pointless to pick apart Mars Attacks on any level be it storytelling, acting, or technical specs because it's pretty much critic proof where you can say it's weird and stupid, but the movie knows it's weird and stupid so any criticism you levy at it will be like you're just describing the movie. I can't tell you if you'll like this movie or not, it'll depend entirely on what your definition of "enjoyable" entails.

Review title: Not some cult classic, just plain awful
Review_body: I saw MARS ATTACKS (1996) back when it first came out and thought it was awful then and it's still awful!
