This is probably the only stain on Tim Burton's 20th century filmography as everything else he did back then like Beetlejuice, the 2 Batman movies starring Miichael Keaton, , Sleepy Hollow, Edward Scissorhands, A Nightmare Before Chiristmas, and still to this day his best film Ed Wood (which should have won Best Picture) were all certified classics and hits and are a testament to his gothic, horror movie style. Mars Attacks is odd man out.This movie is so corny and cheesy with an all-star cast embarrassing themselves either mugging for the camera or being just plain dull. There's this weird dichotomy where it feels like 2 movies. On the one hand, you have Glenn Close, who plays the First Lady, makes goofy facial expressions versus the other where Lukas Haas is the awkward "edgy 90s teens" character. No character was interesting or memorable. In fact, the casting for this movie is weird. You have an iconic actor like Jack Nicholson, but then you have Pierce Brosnan at the start of his tenure as James Bond immediately after he'd just done the great Goldeneye, then there's a super young Natalie Portman right of the heels of the controversial film The Professional, but also Martin Short. Who is ironically one of the few comic actors in this, but I've never found him funny.The intentional over-the-top humor is humorless. The movie is just so silly and unfunny that it amazes me that the movie-going world is now re-assessing this mess as a cult classic. Is it simply because it's 90s Tim Burton and everything else he did in that decade was a hit? I mean, even though his 21st century body of work has been trash, that doesn't mean that he didn't have a stinker in the 20th century and he most definitely did with Mars Attacks!

Review title: A silly, over-the-top sci-fi comedy, one which has improved each time I've seen it
Review_body: This is a Tim Burton film which was made as homage to the sci-fi B-movies of the 1950's. I first saw it in 2006, I guess just a little less than ten years after its release, and during my first viewing, I thought it was pretty bad, even though I hadn't thought that way about any Burton films I had seen before this one! However, I think it was only about 24 hours after that when I watched it for the second time, this time with a slightly better understanding of what the idea of the film was. With that second viewing, I still didn't think it was great, but certainly did find it to be better than I previously had. About four and a half years after those two viewings, I have now seen it for the third time, and this viewing turned out to be even better than the second.Many flying saucers come from Mars and surround planet Earth! The President of the United States, James Dale, is eager to announce this historical event to the country, and when he does, it obviously excites many people. The first of these spaceships lands in the Nevada desert, where a meeting has been set up. Many military personnel and civilians have gathered to witness this landing, and the Martians that come out of the ship are greeted by General Casey. According to a universal translator, these beings claim to have come in peace, and in response to this, a hippie in the crowd releases a dove. However, one of the Martians shoots this dove down while it's flying, and then the extraterrestrials kill many people who are present at this gathering, using laser guns that leave nothing but bones! It is possible that this incident was a "cultural misunderstanding," but this possibility is ruled out when more Martian attacks take place, making it clear that all these creatures want to do is destroy! There are lots of characters in this film, and a very talented cast to play them. Jack Nicholson plays President James Dale, and also plays a more minor character named Art Land. Unsurprisingly, his talent and usual wry style help with the quality of "Mars Attacks!" Glenn Close, Pierce Brosnan, Martin Short, Danny DeVito, Sarah Jessica Parker, etc. also help make the cast as a whole a strong one. As a comedy, this movie isn't usually hilarious, but I still often laughed lightly, and found some occasional big laughs. Most of Press Secretary Jerry Ross' (Martin Short) encounter with a Martian disguised as an Earth woman may not be among the strongest points, but the outcome is perhaps one of the funniest parts of the film! The over-the-top Martians can provide a lot of the humour. To add to the entertainment value, this sci-fi comedy also has many scenes that are bound to have viewers in suspense, plus the special effects and the set design for the inside of the Martian spaceship are very nice to look at.This film came out the same year as "Independence Day", a more popular alien invasion movie, but I personally think that one is overrated and this one is underrated. I actually wasn't impressed with the Roland Emmerich blockbuster at all when I finally saw it all for the first time last year, and think this Tim Burton film is SO much better! If you ask me, this one has better cast performances (nobody here is anything like Randy Quaid as Russell Casse in the other film or those who play that character's offspring, thank goodness), more outstanding characters, and I guess a more entertaining plot. Another reason why "Mars Attacks!" is far superior is perhaps because "Independence Day" takes itself too seriously, which this other alien invasion film of 1996 certainly doesn't. I'm giving this sci-fi comedy an 8/10, even though I've given the same rating to more than one other film directed by Tim Burton which I've found to be better. If you realize that this movie isn't meant to be taken seriously, it could be fun to watch.

My Take: Bizarre and weirdly entertaining. A neat homage to the campy B-movies of the 50's. I don't get it, sometimes, when a movie doesn't take things seriously, people misjudge it as a bad flick. Some of the victims of this misjudging are B-movies. Lots of B-movies get misjudged because they are often times considered as campy, and thus leading to less-than-average ratings. I don't know about some critics, but "Mars Attacks!" is a great parody of 50's B-alien invasion movies. I loved MARS ATTACKS! the first time I saw it, and it gets better in every subsequent viewing. MARS ATTACKS! is an odd acquired taste that literally grows on you. This film was probably Tim's second tribute to inept B-filmmaker Edward "Ed Wood" D. Jr (The first was 1994's "Ed Wood"). He really spent a big-budget, to make it look like a "low-budget" B-movie. The costumes and sets inside the Martians' flying saucers resemble that of Stanley Kubrick's "A Clockwork Orange" or Wood's ultra low-budgeted "Plan 9 from Outer Space". It seems Burton himself has become Wood himself. Then again, what better way to pay homage to someone than to be that someone yourself, right? In a way, Burton has a lot of fun with all of this.MARS ATTACKS! is a witty well-done B-movie. Just as the big-headed, slimy-brained Martians, Burton goes "to-hell-with-it" and goes wild with it. The first hour, which plays like an Irwin Allen disaster movie row-call, is the weaker half of the film, but it creates a sarcastic view of humanity and pop culture while faithfully pokes fun at the naivety and foolishness of B-movie characters that it still works. In the second act, Burton literally goes wild; blowing everything up and throwing witty homages to every B-movie cliché in the book. It's not for all tastes, but anyone who has a bizarre taste for camp cinema will surely treasure MARS ATTACKS! It can be said that, if Ed Wood had the budget, PLAN 9 would have looked just like this. Rating: ****1/2 out of 5.

Review title: Just What The Hell Was That Anyway?
Review_body: Suggested by a series of kiddie trading cards deemed so subversively violent that they were pulled from the market, MARS ATTACKS! is a film that tends to divide viewers into "love it" and "hate it" camps. Those who love it enjoy its mix of homage and originality and its remarkably black sense of humor. Those who hate it feel that the humor becomes so black that it descends into a sort of lowbrow meanspiritedness that undermines any amusement involved. Strange to say, they're both right.The story is the classic "alien invasion" tale given increasingly weird twists. The United States decides to construe the arrival of a Martian fleet of flying saucers as a friendly arrival--but alas, the Martians have a sense of humor so distasteful that a herd of drunken frat boys look like Noel Coward in comparison. Cattle catch fire and stampede! Heads are switched with pet dogs! Congress is wiped out by ray gun! Can a highly unnatural pairing of Slim Whitman and Tom Jones save the day? Well, you never know.The film is rife with sight-gags, and when they work they work go off with a bang--with the Las Vegas scenes the high point of the film. It is true that the Martians are a tacky bunch, but it's hard to be tackier than Vegas, and director Tim Burton successfully works the joke to the nth degree. Trouble is, the rest of the film isn't at quite same level. It's presented as a joke, but it's hard to laugh when the residents of a retirement home are reduced to wheelchair-bound skeletons. MARS ATTACKS reaches for laugh after laugh, but too often the reach is funny and the pay off isn't.The film has a host of actors, some famous, some infamous, and some just plain camp. Jack Nicholson does double duty as President of the United States and a Las Vegas promoter; Glenn Close scores as the First Lady; Lisa-Marie is weirdly snakey as the "Martian Girl;" and Sylvia Sidney is memorable as the semi-senile Granny armed with Slim Whitman records. There are a lot more: Rod Steiger, Pierce Brosman, Sarah Jessica Parker, Pam Greer, and so on, and most of them are as hit and miss as the film itself. I have to confess an unexpected liking for Tom Jones, who dives into the thing feet first and proves a lot fun. But it's the look and style that carry the thing, and it's all very "What the hell was that?" The DVD is truly no frills, although it does contain a few "Martian" jokes that are (somewhat like the film) more annoying than actually funny. Recommended as a curiosity and with the warning that you should rent it before you buy it: if you love it, you'll be more than ready to whip out the cash, but if you hate it, you'll grit your teeth for having spent a dime.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

Review title: Misinterpreted? Unlikely. Unusually bad Burton makes big let down
Review_body: The US government receives intelligence from outer space that aliens from Mars are coming to earth, which soon spells disaster for the entire world.Tim Burton, director, producer and writer. An artist. Edward Scissorhands, Beetle Juice and Batman, are all loved and praised to this day. Jack Nicholson: Chinatown, Cuckoo's Nest, Easy Rider. Oscar winner. All these lists sadly mean little when you sit back in your comfy chair in the evening to watch a cool sci-fi film for the first time by two of the biggest names in the business, and you are left wishing you had taken an early night.Roland Emmerich's smash Independence Day a few months previously was an outstanding collaboration of up and coming stars that brought visual effects and stunning cinematography to a whole new appreciation. Mars Attacks could not compete, even if it was released before.Burton's picture is disappointing on numerous factors. For me, I have come to really love and appreciate his work. The darkness and simplicity of his stories and directional style make him unique in this competitive business and so I have a high expectancy for each of his works. So this 1996 release was disappointing as it copied a previous release almost word for word and the darkness and strangeness of his previous smashes were left out. Another factor for the film's bombing is the positing of the story against the situation. For example when the aliens first arrive there are TV reporter's standing on their caravans giving exceptionally bad speeches to the world. And none of this generates realism and is simply awful positing from a director who should really have known better.The story has been discussed numerous times over the years. Having looked on the IMDb discussion board it seems many find this a stab at other star driven Blockbusters. If that is the case, then the whole spoof concept is amazingly inaccurate as it tries to be real sci-fi and frightening. Encoding issues of alcoholism and business dealings, not to mention an embarrassing look at sex from Martin Short, makes the whole thing weighed down with impossible objectives that it would never have filled.Nicholson, Close, Brosnan, Bening and Fox may have had some astounding films in the past but none of their achievements are worthy of association with this consistently bad picture. Nicholson has actually never been so flat and uninteresting.In comparison to Independence Day, Mars Attacks revolves around aliens coming to earth and attempt a take over. But oddly this intentional comedy is less funny than the Will Smith star maker. Plus these effects are soft whereas the other is spellbinding.Remember 1977 when Star Wars broke minds? Remember the Phantom Menace? That was the biggest disappointment in Sci-Fi history. For me, seeing Burton and Nicholson subjected to an ordinary plot with unfunny intentions is the biggest disappointment

Review title: Great spoof, no matter how silly it gets
Review_body: I you're a sci-fi fan you might like this film, you might not. If you're a Tim Burton fan you might like this film, or you might not. I you're a fan of mixed genre films you might like this film, you might not. Personally, I really liked this wacky little flick. Mars Attacks! is a spoof of 1950's sci-fi movies, poking fun at all their cheese and cliché. It centers around a variety of characters spread out amongst the USA and how they all react and cope with a martian invasion. There's nothing in this film to take seriously and, for what it's worth, I found it to be hilarious and a ridiculous amount of fun, no matter how stupid it can be.Mars Attacks! is, in a way, genius. It is the kind of movie that is designed in such a way that you can't critique it. You can dislike it, or even hate it, but you can't necessarily critique it on any specific element. The reason being is that it spoofs a genre and a time period for that genre, so anything that is cheesy, silly, or stupid can be accredited to the film's spoofing. If a character does something irrational and idiotic, it is spoofing the way characters were in so many of those cheesy 50's flicks. If something totally bizarre and unbelievable happens in the plot, blame it on the genre the film is spoofing. This kind of manipulations practically falls under the category of film treachery, but I have to give the film credit for finding a loophole around any and all imperfections.And as far as imperfections go, Mars Attacks! has a lot of them. It is a ridiculous, absurd, unrealistic, and plot hole ridden film. Half of it makes no sense and the other half we just sort of have to go with. But the brilliant thing is, that's all part of the fun. This film isn't made to take seriously, and neither is it made to be criticized and scrutinized. It is meant to be enjoyed and only aims to be silly and entertaining. Some will see it as an uncreative way to force us to enjoy this movie, I see it as an opportunity to have a great time and numerous laughs.Another thing I have to give Mars Attacks! plenty of props for is production value. The film rounds up an all star cast of characters with everyone from Danny DeVito to Jack Black. It is also just a large scale flick with lots of great actions sequences with plenty of explosions and giant collapsing buildings. The martians themselves are completely CGI. They look cool to me but I'm unsure if the CGI would be considered good or bad for 1996. I would have to go back and compare it to other special effects of the 90's. The film may looks cheesy but, once again, that just goes back to the fact that everything about this film is cheesy because that is what it is spoofing. But when you think about it, a good amount of money and construction went into making this film as exciting and big budget cheesy as possible, and for that I have to commend it.Mars Attacks! isn't what you would call a high quality film, but that doesn't stop it from being pretty damn fun. I couldn't stop myself from laughing at the cheesiness, the irony, and the satire that is littered throughout this film. I see this is a great use of satire, and it is a spoof film that I can actually stand to watch, and that's saying a lot considering my alternatives would be Epic Movie or Vampires Suck. Mars Attacks! accomplishes what it sets out to do, and so I had a really great time with it.

Okaaaay, aaaand 50,000 points is awarded to Mars Attacks!, for having the awesomest cast of A-list actors in all of movie history! DING * DING * DING * DING * DING * DING * DING Congratulations, Mars Attacks! Here now to claim their prize on the behalf of the filmmakers, please give a warm, Earthly welcome to the Martian Ambassador, from Mars! ACK! ACK! ACK! ACK! Wait, no! Audience, watch out! Get out of here, quick! Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh! Let's work our way through these top stars, shall we - Jack Nicholson is the coolest actor in Hollywood. Natalie Portman is the starlet of her generation. Glenn Close possesses such a prominent prestige. Annette Bening is peppy and very fine. The smart and sleek Pierce Brosnan who is oh so dashing. The greatly adored Michael J. Fox. America's Sweetheart, Sarah Jessica Parker. Danny DeVito, don't count him out. The strong and sexy Pam Grier. The endearingly hilarious Martin Short, who is so endearingly hilarious. The largely exuberant Jack Black. The rambunctiously sweet Christina Applegate. The greatest man in Vegas, Tom Jones. And the greatest football running-back, Jim Brown. Not too shabby, and you might even recognize a few more familiar faces.Let's work our way through their performances, shall we - Nicholson is purely Jack, 'nough said. Natalie Portman is too good. Close can overact with the best of 'em. Bening is endlessly appealing as a free spirit. Mr. Brosnan insists on pleasing. Michael J. Fox is really good at summoning his inner jerk. Sarah J. is too intelligent to act so witless. DeVito is noticeable even among the biggest stars. Pam Grier is openly big-hearted as she strengthens her legacy as an actress. Marty Short bares a comical confidence. Jack Black has a lot to give and seems preparing for fame. Christina Applegate is briefly buoyant. Tom Jones should stick to singing. And Jim Brown is actually pretty darn decent, he steals the spotlight.Mars Attacks! has good effects, considerable entertainment value, and it is pieced together nicely. Tim Burton loves to take every opportunity to delve into the dark arts, but his talents are best served on the lighter side, case in point, this and Edward Scissorhands.

Completely dumb comedy that is saved from being offensively unfunny only by virtue of it's good-naturedness.Not that the good-naturedness extends that far: violence, mutilation and graphic destruction permeate the movie. I cannot really slate Mars Attacks! as there are people that enjoy this kind of humour, and I must accept that "screwball" comedies are very amusing to some people. Personally if I see John Candy on a screen I tend to switch over, but I gave this one a go.Of course, it's all just a jokey satire on 50s B-Movies, but then satire implies wit. This is really lame, with stars like Jack Nicholson and Tom Jones sending themselves up rotten. Yet such stars already walk a tightrope between credibility and self-parody anyway, so there's really no need to send themselves up. It's like Arnold Schwarzennegger hamming it up in one of his "comedies" - Arnie, people laugh at you anyway, you don't need to try.I did laugh at Mars Attacks! - well, twice. Once when the fictitious boxer Byron Williams gets reminded by Art Land (Nicholson, unfunny) of his bout in "The Quaker In Jamaica". I also chuckled when the Martians first started to explode upon hearing Slim Whitman. The first time, anyway. Fifty times later and the "joke" had started to wear a bit thin.But it all seems such a waste. The budget was $70 million, yet the CGI effects already look cheap. But the excess of underused talent here is shocking. I don't know, maybe it's just me, but seeing Rod Steiger sacrifice his dignity by being shrunk to microscopic size, paraphrasing Winston Churchill and then being stamped on by a Martian seems a disrespectful moment. Pierce Brosnan gives a better performance here than he ever does as James Bond, though if seeing his disembodied head talking to Sarah Jessica Parker's on the body of a dog makes you laugh, then watch this. Personally I found it witless, charmless and pathetic.Also notable is the sheer disregard for the totty on display. Christina Applegate (the randy daughter from "Married With Children") is here, though is only in a single scene, while Natalie Portman only gets to deliver occasional one-liners. Many national monuments are destroyed - The Houses of Parliament in England; The Eiffel Tower in France; The Taj Mahal in India; yet patriotically The White House is left virtually unscathed. And the joke with Mount Rushmore was done much better in Superman II.Actors that are normally amusing, such as Danny DeVito, are encouraged to overact, as are all the cast, obliterating any essence of humour. Ultimately, it seems the sort of film that all the cast and crew had a real hoot making, yet fails to translate to the audience. Desperate and painfully unfunny.

Review title: A Hilarious Tribute To Alien Invasion B Movies with Burton Flavor
Review_body: Watched Mars Attacks! Featuring Jack Nicholson(Batman) as President James Dale/ Art Land , Glenn Close(Hamlet) as First Lady Marsha Dale , Pierce Brosnan(Goldeneye 007 ) as Professor Donald Kessler ,Danny DeVito(Batman Returns) as Rude Gambler,Annette Bening(Richard III) as Barbara Land ,Martin Short(Father Of The Bride II) as Press Secretary Jerry Ross, Sarah Jessica Parker(The Substance Of Fire) as Nathalie Lake, Michael J.Fox(Back To The Future) as Jason Stone, Rod Steiger(Shiloh) as General Decker, Lukas Haas(The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles) as Richie Norris,Natalie Portman(Leon The Professional) as Taffy Dale, Jim Brown(L.A. Heat) as Bryon Williams, Sylvia Sydney(Used People) as Florence Norris , Pam Grier(Jackie Brown) as Louise Williams, Jack Black(The X-Files) as Billy-Glenn Norris and Tom Jones as Himself . The film is interesting and one of my favorite Burton films with 1950's B Sci-Fi Flavor as well Burtons Own spin also very Hilarious Also A Parody of Independence as well also enjoyed the heavy handed cast as well . Amazing Score By Danny Elfman( Ed Wood), Costume Design By Coleen Atwood(That Thing You Do!) ,Cinematography By Peter Suschitzsky (Krull) ,Screenplay by Jonathan Gems(White Mischief) , Direction By Tim Burton(Beetlejuice) A Hilarious Tribute To Alien Invasion B Movies with Burton Flavor 7/10

Though it's certainly not among Tim Burton's greatest works, Mars Attacks! is, in many ways, the perfect follow-up to his masterpiece Ed Wood, because it's a direct homage to every trashy sci-fi B-movie from the 40's, 50's and 60's, and Mr. Wood's own works are high on that list. It's a common error that Mars Attacks! was intended as a spoof on Independence Day, which was a huge hit that very same year, and was in fact produced and filmed simultaneously; of course, Mars Attacks! spoofs the very same films that Independence Day paid homage to, even if, as many have already noted, it's actually officially based on trading cards from the late 60's, which inspired the way the Martians look. In Mars Attacks! Mr. Burton shows the kind of pop-culture sensitivity we're more accustomed to seeing in Quentin Tarantino's work, with relatively very little of his own vision and motives in it; he does a master job of copying the style of the horrible films he loved so much as a child, and so even though it's his least personal film  to that point, that is  there's also quite a bit of him in it, though not in the way that we're used to from Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood and even Batman.Tim Burton lets himself loose on Mars Attacks! like no other movie since Pee Wee's Big Adventure. It's strictly visual comedy, and just like Pee Wee's Big Adventure and Beetlejuice, the success of the film is first and foremost due to his direction, and very little thanks to the script, which is minimal and quite simplistic. Burton gathered an all-star cast which includes Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Jack Black, Lisa Marie, Rod Steiger, Annette Bening, Michael J. Fox, Denny DeVito, Pierce Brosnan, Sarah Jessica Parker, Jim Brown, Martin Short, Pam Grier, Natalie Portman and Tom Jones in a fantastic performance as himself, and with the help of that cast he created what may just be his most outright hilarious comedy, which is also a clever and subtle parody. It's not essential viewing but it's one hell of a wild ride and probably Tim Burton's most easily accessible work.

Review title: A well meaning B-grade movie with a large budget!
Review_body: Martians come to Earth and create havoc by shoving it up patriotic Yankee lets-kick-some-butt attitude. Some hilarious moments in this uneven film with a perfect solution in destroying the nasty Martians. Call Ed Wood back from the grave, he would have loved this art trash film.

Review title: Hysterical, wacky and irriverent... and underrated!
Review_body: I have always loved this movie since the first time I saw it (June 2012). During these years I rewatched it a few times and I always liked it the same way I liked it when I saw it for the first time. I also think that this movie is very underrated because here on IMDB it has 6,3 and both many positive reviews and many negative reviews. When I look at the many negative reviews I do think that they don't get the sense of this movie as this is pretty much a satire on how politics treats their enemies and also a parody on 1950s' science movies. And the fact I re-watched it at least 5 times says a lot!The movie is about some Martians that comes on Earth for invading it. I already said the plot because what follows it's a series of hilarious vignettes involving many characters and the Martians. I'll tell some: when the Martians arrive in the Utah desert they start their killing spree and kill the news reporters and private Billy Glenn Norris (Jack Black); when the president James Dale (Jack Nicholson) is isolated in the bunker has a discussion with General Decker (Rod Steiger) and screams ''SHUT UUUUUP! SHUT UP SHUT UP SHUT UUP!'' It makes roll from laughter every time; When the night before the president receives a call from the President of France then we see the aliens that attack with laser guns all the French politics and outside we see the Eiffel Tower fall in crumbles; the nuclear attack to Mars fails and then we see scenes of the Martians that destroys all of Earth's major monuments (including the Rushmore Mountain, the Taj Mahal, some huge Las Vegas casinos and others).Now tell me, are those scenes funny? YES a LOT!The cast does a great job. Jack Nicholson is probably the best of all the big names in the cast in a dual role. As the President is so loud and irritable in his outbursts that it makes me laugh a lot every time! Annette Bening is my other favourite performer in the movie as she looks so gorgeous despite being a recovering alcoholic. Jack Black, Danny de Vito, Rod Steiger, Pierce Brosnan, Michael J Fox and few others give good supporting performances as well. The soundtrack is the second great thing of this movie since it fits like a glove what happens in the movie. And it's also very catchy in spots. The special effects are very cool for 1996 standards and they didn't aged a lot IMO since they look so realistic.I think that I have said all that I had inside my chest about this movie and won't say a lot anymore. I would suggest to anyone who hasn't seen it... Watch it!!! It's so funny and hilarious that you will even forget the time spent watching it and it's the perfect movie for a lazy afternoon.

Review title: If you have a warped sense of humour, you'll enjoy this
Review_body: Tim Burton's film, 'Mars Attacks!' combines elements of dark humour with an alien invasion to create a hilarious film. There's no doubt about it that audiences will be torn between those who enjoyed the film (the comedy) and those who hated it. This film is a parody of other Earth-invasion films, such as 'Independence Day' and 'War of the Worlds', which have been a common theme in story-telling for decades and particularly in the 1950s. In this film, the aliens are content on destroying Earth and humiliating the humans for the sake of it. It's not a serious film at all, and you'll either love it or hate it, depending on how warped your sense of humour is. I thought it was fun, even though it is not the best film of all time.

I enjoyed this film.Basically parody on everything! Jack Nicholson is so great that his quote: Why don*t we all just get along? is so many times repeated.Why don*t we all just get along? That is a goo question.I do not think we can.Earth is to diverse and generally poor.Poor us.Mars will not attack us.But we will each other, all the time.Generally I recommend this film, but do not take it seriously! Just have fun!

Review title: Comedy Films Of The 90's: Mars Attacks!
Review_body: Mars Attacks! (1996): Starring Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Bening, Martin Short, Natalie Portman, Pierce Brosnan, Sarah Jessica Parker, Michael J. Fox, Danny Devito, Rod Steiger, Pam Grier, Tom Jones, Christina Applegate, Jack Black, Paul Winfield. Director Tim Burton, Screenplay Jonathan Gems.At first glance, Mars Attacks is a hilarious and colorful spoof of "Independence Day" (1995), but it also parodies science fiction/flying saucer films of the 1950's. While audiences generally disliked this comedy, no where else will you find a genuinely funny and fun film that boasts a cast of Hollywood icons like Danny Devito, Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Bening, Martin Short, Pierce Brosnan, Pam Grier and Michael J. Fox, who are each straying from their usual repertoire and doing some good, zany, offbeat comedy. The premise: A race of funny-looking aliens who talk like ducks come to earth, betray a peace pact with humans and begin to rain destruction over dozens of cities, including Las Vegas. Alien specialist Barbara Land (Annette Bening) welcomes the aliens along with her hippie-like, New Age, alien enthusiast friends. Jack Nicholson portrays the President, in a role that he is clearly having fun with. Glenn Close, also, is having fun in the role of the First Lady. Natalie Portman, not yet a well-known actress, plays their daughter Taffy Dale. Martin Short plays Jerry Ross the Press Secretary who in a memorably humorous scene attempts to seduce an alien who has assumed the shape of a beautiful, tall striking woman with a beehive hairdo. Sarah Jessica Parker portrays Nathalie, a news reporter covering the invasion, who is in a relationship with political activist Jason Stone (Michael J. Fox). Nathalie falls for the brilliant and sexy Professor Donald Kessler (Pierce Brosnan) and both become victims of the alien's transformation power, so that for much of the film we see Sarah Jessica Parker's head on the body of a dog and the head of Pierce Brosnan inside a glass container. It's hilarious! Pam Grier, taking on the tough black girl/single mother persona she does so well, portrays Louise Williams whose husband is in the army and an obvious black G.I.Joe type of guy. Sure, much of this is outlandish, cartoonish and appears to cater to child-like audiences, but it's an entertaining movie nonetheless. And although no one saw it at the time, this movie paved the way for the more successful space alien comedies Men In Black. Mars Attacks is well-written, with characters who, although flat and straight out of comic books, are interesting. You have to be able to suspend disbelief in order to enjoy this movie and you have to be willing to lose yourself in the laughter, as this is the kind of film that depends on visual and spoken comedy. This is a document of comedy films of the 1990's, but the kind of comedy that is specifically targeting a demographic- younger, fans of alien invasion movies and fans of good comedy.

This movie had been on my 'must see' list for a long time, but now I know I've been expecting too much. All ingredients seemed to be there, a sci-fi spoof with Burton as director and a cast full of stars. Comes to show names don't tell all...I don't know what Burton really tries with this one... it's not funny enough for a spoof (I actually don't think I laughed even once) and not 'real' enough to be an actual science-fiction flick... so what's going on here?As for the actors, they seem puzzled as well what they are doing here... Nicholson is pretty good in his dubble role and Tom Jones has a funny part... that's about it.Oh and I thought of one good joke, when Portman says something like 'it wasn't the doves', when the aliens strike for the second time... but for the rest, as I said, bleh...3/10.

Review title: good film despite of some minor glitches.
Review_body: If my memory serves me correctly Mars Attacks! wasn't a critical nor a commercial success. Though I might be wrong about that commercial part.But anyway, here's the deal: Mars Attacks! is hilarious parody from all those sci-fi flicks where aliens in their flying saucers come to take on the world just for the heck of it. And in this case it really, REALLY is for the heck of it: the martians have the most sickest sense of the humor in the whole universe. Hence forth the movie is mainly a black comedy, which actually is not anything new for Tim Burton. So thats the plot. Detrcution of the world, in hilarious manner.So the cast, ah, what a wonderful cast. Jack Nicholson in double role as the president of U.S.A and as a sleazy casino owner Art Land. Pierce Brosnan as Donald Kessler, a scientist, who is sure about peaceful (hah) purposes of the martians. Sarah Jessica Parker as bimbo reporter Natalie Lake, Michael J. Fox as her rival/boyfriend Jason Stone. and numerous of other small parts for Danny DeVito, Natalie Portman etc. It really is a fireworks of talented actors. Music is made by Danny Elfman, as it usually is in Burton film, and it fits like a glove in the quirky atmosphere of the movie. And Burtons direction is sturdy and good, or at least it is better than his direction was in Planet of The Apes.Special effects are decent. They don't blow your mind, but then again I have a feeling, that if all the computer animation was done today, the movie would still look exactly the same: cheaply made sci-fi flick. That is the style and it works well.But, the reason I cannot give this movie a better score is the overall plot, which does cut some curves and has some scenes that just don't work as good as the rest of the movie. But over all this is a good, entertaining (if you like black humor) flick.

It's fascinating to see Tim Burton fail on an epic scale. The problem with the movie is as simple as the title -- the earth is under attack and the director is rooting for the Martians!Why does Tim Burton love the Martians so much? Because they're mean, ugly, and weird-looking, and because they hate the people he hates. Small town jocks, the military, the squares, the working class, the poor . . . anybody who's not fabulous and weird and from someplace glittering with excess, insanity, and money. Like Bel Air and Beverly Hills.The irony is, the director's vision totally contradicts the story line itself. The structure of the screenplay really focuses on decent, ordinary earth people who become survivors. In that regard the movie is less like The Day The Earth Stood Still or The Thing From Another World, and more like Seventies disaster epics like Earthquake and The Towering Inferno.In those old Seventies epics, you had a huge cast drawn from different backgrounds, rich or poor, black or white. And then when disaster hits, unexpected heroes are revealed, and old relationships are strengthened while new ones are formed.But hey, Burton can't be bothered with that stuff. Let's watch the squares burn!

Review title: Frying the Camp of Science Fiction
Review_body: Tim Burton made "Mars Attacks!" as a spoof of science fiction movies of the golden age.  And since it was released around the same time as "Independence Day," you can't help but see a parody of that as well.  The story has ugly aliens from Mars attacking Earth for no reason other than a lark.  The movie is full of visual jokes that are enjoyable.  The violence can be a little disturbing at times.  Jack Nicholson gives a fun dual performance as President Dale, and as Las Vegas casino mogul Art Land.  Glenn Close does a funny spoof of Nancy Reagan as the First Lady, while Paul Winfield plays the part of a pseudo-General Colin Powell.  The ending is ridiculous, but it fits with the silly tone of the movie.  What else can you say about a movie that features disembodied heads making out, and using the statues of Easter Island as bowling pins?

Review title: Burton's homage to 50's B-films nearly becomes what it is supposed to spoof.
Review_body: There is no doubt that Tim Burton is truly a unique filmmaker and even though I didn't much enjoy any of his Batman adventures, I did think that both Ed Wood and Edward Scissorhands were pure movie magic.Now, this is supposed to be an homage to schlock cinema, and as many will probably think Burton's attempt to make an Ed Wood film of his own, even though his budget is considerably higher. On that level it succeeds beautifully. Everybody mouths their lines like they think that they are in the worst movie of all time. Especially Danny DeVito, who has swallowed his artistic side and gone back to the character he played in "Romancing the Stone" and "Jewel of the Nile". Those films were also pure B-movies and had some A-list actors in the cast.As for Jack Nicholson's dual role as the President and the Texan Casino owner, you can only hope that he had a lot of fun doing it. To think that this is the same man who has so many Oscar nominations and 3 wins to his name and appears with totally bizarre dentures in this film is mindboggling. Glenn Close looks embarrassed to be in this film and it looks like most of Anette Bening's scenes were cut.Tom Jones as himself is of course brilliant casting (Warning: spoiler): and that he is one of the survivors is also inspired (what would we do without him).So to make a long, boring review even longer (kidding) I had a reasonably good time watching this totally ridiculous time-filler and I hope that Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory will have some of the same style as this piece of eye candy.

Review title: Classic example of how aliens will invade earth one day 7\10
Review_body: "Mars Attacks!" is another big hit by Tim Burton, the setting takes place on Earth, which is being invaded by Martians (or in other words: aliens).The movie is another classic example of how humanity discovers a species of aliens and tries to communicate with them. Only to find out that the aliens have not come in peace. Unlike other movies which show the encounter with aliens, "Mars Attacks!" in particular laughs and makes fun of this sci - fi genre. It is made purposely so ridiculous, whacky and bizarre that it's main intension is just to laugh at humanity.The audience know for sure that a real encounter with aliens will go down way more different than shown here, yet so personally I believe what we just saw on "Mars Attacks!" is a possible outcome.The cast of actors is well wide and impressive: Jack Nicholson, Pierce Brosnan, Sarah Jessica Parker, Annette Bening, Glenn Close and many more.Great movie and great casting, a good and funny screenplay, a really joyful film to watch all together.

This movie is hilarious! It is a great spoof of those sci-fi B-movies of the `50s. The film doesn't have Burton's usual cast of players but the A-list cast does well. It's sad that this is Burton's first flop. Then again after eleven years he gets his first flop. How many directors have gotten their first flop after eleven years?

Mars Attacks! (1996, Dir. Tim Burton) It is a normal day for everyone, until the President of the United States. They are able to get in contact with the Martians, and arrange for a meeting behind them and us humans. But not everything goes to plan, and the Martians have other plans for Earth. Are they just misunderstood beings? or do they really want to destroy all of humanity.When you see a film with Tim Burton's name on it, you know it's going to be something special. Mars Attacks! is nothing short of that. The story is there with enough action to keep you hooked. The action is top standard, even from Tom Jones. Jack Nicholson is just amazing in this playing two characters. The special effects are a mixed bag nowadays. Some of the effects still looked good such as the spaceships, but some CGI looked a bit dodgy, such as the green slime against the walls. This doesn't reduce the fun though, and you still have an enjoyable viewing experience, even after ten years."I'm not having that thing in my house." - First Lady (Glenn Close)

Mars Attacks! is a piss-take through and through. It takes the controversial trading cards of the 60s and creates a movie around them, taking the opportunity to poke fun and as many old sci-fi films as possible. It's parody, it's satire, and in some ways it's even an homage. If this tone doesn't immediately strike you when you watch it, you're missing the point. On its surface level, Mars Attacks! is just silly. It's absurd nonsense. But make no mistake, this is kind of the point. It wants you to look at those old sci-fi/horror movies from the 50s and 60s and realise how ridiculous they were. The flying Saucers with satellite-dish ray guns coming out the bottom and destroying buildings, the stampede of flaming cows, the frankensteining of human captives to create disturbing chimeras with animals, the cowardly president delivering a defiant speech. It's meant to be ridiculousThat said I find Mars Attacks! was almost designed in such a way that it would be easy to miss the point. The satire is clever and witty, but not always obvious. I don't think I would ever describe Mars Attacks! as a laugh out loud comedy. It certainly has its moments, for sure, but its goal wasn't to make you laugh heartily every five minutes. It's a more thoughtful comedy, comedy that requires dissection to find the joke. It demands a smirk now and a hearty chuckle later when the implications really hit you. If nothing else it's humour is dark. Super dark. If you can't find the humour in people being vaporised, Mars Attacks! is not the movie for you.My most recent rewatch I actually found really rewarding in a number of ways. For starters, I never realised the insane amount of A-listers there are in this movie, and most of them are glorified cameos. Danny DeVito, for instance, has a couple of lines and then dies, he's barely on screen for a full minute, but this is Danny DeVito in the mid-90s! Glenn Close doesn't fair much better, nor does Michael J Fox (in his last ever live-action appearance no less). On the other hand Jack Nicholson gets to play two characters at opposite ends of the country. Then there's Natalie Portman, Jack Black, and Lukas Haas, all young and pre-fame. Annette Bening plays the most un-Bening character I've ever seen her play, while Pierce Brosnan and Sarah Jessica Parker share the most brutal fates. Tom Jones makes an appearance as himself, oh and Pam Grier stops a bus to retrieve her truanting sons.Another thing I never realised about this movie before, but makes so much sense in retrospect, is how much they actually got away with. The design of the aliens is horrifying. Skeletal, big bulging eyes, and brainheads. They even have little wiggling appendages under their cheeks. They're pure nightmare fuel. The complete brutality and cruelty exhibited by the Martians is even worse. They come down and appear friendly just to mess with humanity, and then vaporise everyone. And not just tame disintegration you usually get in movies, no, their rayguns strip the flesh from your bones leaving only charred remains. The most horrifying though is the fate of Sarah Jessica Parker and Pierce Brosnan who are subject to human experimentation. Their bodies are taken apart and dissected while they're still alive. Brosnan ends up as just a disembodied head suspended from the ceiling with BLOOD STILL DRIPPING FROM HIS NECK, while Parker suffers a head swap with her dog, which is equally as disturbing to actually see. How did this get passed the censors? And this was the toned down version as well! Originally the rayguns were going to have a wider variety of effects, but they had to tone them down to vaporising to avoid a hard R-rating. And this is all without mentioning the bizarrely creepy movements of 'Martian Girl' which is always oddly unnerving to watch.Mars Attacks! man. What a movie. It's been over twenty years and I still can't believe this actually got made. On paper it looks like a terrible idea: Let's assemble a huge cast of expensive A-listers and put them in a sci-fi parody that looks intentionally cheap. We'll make it visually terrifying yet colourful, kill off almost all the A-listers, and market it to a younger audience. While I'm not as bigger a lover of the movie as some (like my wife), it still holds a special place in my heart. I will always be nostalgic and have a fondness for it. I give it a solid 7/10. You definitely need to approach it at the right angle from the offset. This isn't Independence Day.P.S. It ends with Tom Jones singing 'It's Not Unusual' with a bald eagle on his arm. That's all that needs to be said really.

Review title: a comedy for every sci-fi fan
Review_body: This movie have martians who watch tv and steal and dance, jack nicholson as the president and pierce brosnan as a cientific, and the movie have alot of jokes between the start and the end. Even tom jones sining was funny. You cant take this movie serious, is a comedy with sci-fi, and every single scene contains some kind of joke.theres so many jokes to remember .

Although I've known about the existence of this movie for over a decade, I never actually watched the whole thing from start to finish until last week. Maybe the reason I put it off for so long is because I didn't know what to expect, other than a fairly generic alien invasion movie. Beings from another world trying to conquer the earth is not anything new in science fiction, and even in the 1800s people like HG Wells were entertaining (and scaring) people with this topic. One thing that kind of annoys me about this genre is that the aliens are almost always portrayed as having intelligence humans can only dream of, but still can't figure out that violence resolves nothing. They even say how the aliens in this movie are a peaceful race by definition because they're smarter than humans. Before this all gets introduced to us, we are made aware of the fact that a massive armada of flying saucers from Mars is taking off and venturing earthward. As is usually the case, it's up to America to fix everything. The US president James Dale (Jack Nicholson) is trying to work with his advisors and military officers to determine how best to handle this once in a lifetime situation. They decide not to unleash america's nuclear arsenal and provoke a war humanity will probably lose. Instead, Dale gives the army permission to prepare a specified landing zone for the martian ships in the Nevada desert. When the ship lands, the (surprisingly short) aliens emerge, as soldiers and tank drivers look on in bewilderment. Using a machine that is somehow about to understand martian speech, an american general steps up to them and welcomes them to earth. The aliens say they come in peace. Immediately after, a man from the crowd releases a morning dove into the air to celebrate the new human-martian alliance. Unfortunately, the martians misinterpret the bird as a weapon and disintegrate it with their ray guns. An extremely one-sided gunfight breaks out, and the martians effortlessly destroy and kill many of the vehicles and men at the landing site. Shortly after, the president receives another message from the martians, saying how they are willing to apologize and now want to address the US Congress to set things right. The saucer lands again, this time in front of the capitol building. Once inside the Congress, the martian ambassador takes the lectern, with two bodyguards by his side. Right when everything seems nice and calm, they draw their guns and reduce most of the senators in the room to skeletons. By now, the entire world is being turned into a laughing stock. The martian forces are able to kill with impunity, and landmarks around the world begin to fall to their forces. Eventually, they attack the white house itself and Dale is forced by the secret service to flee. The martians try to coax the president into a truce after they break into his bunker, and then kill him. Right as all hope seems lost, a band of survivors discover by complete accident that while the martians are seemingly immune to atomic weapons, guns, and everything else, playing Slim Whitman music through a loudspeaker has debilitating effects on them. Soon, militaries all over earth put down their weapons in order to blast these songs from everywhere. Even the martians inside the spaceships have their heads explode and their invasion is foiled. After seeing this, I can certainly understand why it got the response it did upon being released. People generally felt the movie was impressive visually, but wasn't very original. For the most part, that's correct. Tim Burton wanted this movie to be a parody of already-existing alien invasion films, especially the huge amount of them that came out of the 1950s. This means Mars Attacks has somewhat of an excuse to justify its lack of creativity. It's simply mediocre on purpose. The types of weapons the martians use which are able to blast people into skeletons is also a trope you'd see in something like War of the Worlds. If you've seen The Day the Earth Stood Still, you'll probably notice the similarities between the scenes where the aliens first come to earth. In that film, the spaceman pulls out a device intended for the president, and the army shoots at him, thinking it's a weapon. The martians mistaking the dove for a weapon is basically a homage to that. I just thought it was entertaining to see the president's daughter (Natalie Portman) award the survivors for their heroism right after her father was martyred by the aliens. In my view, the movie was entertaining even though its amount of originality is pretty subpar, because Burton managed to parody 50s sci-fi a little too well.

Except for his two BATMAN films, I really like the work of Tim Burton. Sure, his scripts may not hold together, but there's an appealing subversive streak of humor that appeals to me, and his visual talent is not slated towards beating us over the head with special effects, but with creating worlds that inspire us even if(especially if) we chuckle at them.MARS ATTACKS! was not well-liked by many, but I had a great time at it. The film may be intended as a tribute to(as well as a parody of) those cheesy 1950's sci-fi flicks, but it also serves as a wicked satire of the disaster flick, exemplified that year with INDEPENDENCE DAY.  Obviously, the main attraction is those Mars creatures, which, through a combination of stop-motion animation and computer graphics, are great to look at and provide several great moments in the film(especially when their heads explode).  But the humans do alright as well.  Sure, Jack Nicholson is one-note as the real estate developer(I'm reminded here that when Burton asked Nicholson which part he wanted to play, Nicholson replied, "How about all of them?"), and Natalie Portman and Danny DeVito are wasted as, respectively, the First Daughter and a gambler.  But Nicholson does good work as the President, Glenn Close is hysterical as the First Lady, Annette Bening finally gets to play Catwoman(so to speak), and the cast is filled with people like Jim Brown and Pam Grier, who know enough not to take it seriously.  A lot of fun!

Review title: I was really hoping for a better movie...
Review_body: I love sci-fi, especially with aliens. This movie came shortly after the much better Independence day and Men In Black, so I was hoping for something of that calibre. The cast was quite good, and Tim Burton often is...but this movie was very disappointing. There were some fun bits, but the aliens were mostly annoying. Some acting was really terrible and even years later I was anxious to rewatch it, hoping it was better than I remembered...but it wasn't.

I have only one thing to say about "Mars Attacks!": very funny! I just love movies like this. Granted, it is seriously weird, but that is what makes it so good. And it was great fun to see all these actors (too many to mention here) in the same film. And to make it even more perfect: Tom Jones!! :-) (6/10)

Review title: Mars Attacks! must be viewed as a major disappointment, considering the talent and money involved.
Review_body: Director Tim Burton possesses a brilliant touch and has turned out enduring delights such as Ed Wood, Pee Wee's Big Adventure, Beetlejuice and Edward Scissorhands. He is bound to have an off day, and one critic has already described the bloated Mars Attacks! as Burton's 1941. Jack Nicholson heads the big-name cast, playing the president of the United States who must lead the way when Earth is invaded by hordes of short, malicious aliens with big, bulging brains. He watches helplessly as the visitors turn members of Congress into toast with their ray guns. So much for diplomacy. The plot bears some similarities to that summer's biggest hit, Independence Day and to other camp classics from the 1950s, but is just never as funny as was surely intended. Maybe it's because the script is based on Topps Trading Cards. The special effects do look expensive, but grow numbingly repetitive. We could see the same explosions in any movie with Arnie or Sly. Annette Bening, Danny DeVito, Rod Steiger, Lukas Haas, Jim Brown, Paul Winfield, Sylvia Sidney and Christina Applegate pop in for cameos of varying effectiveness. Lisa Marie is totally awesome as a curvaceous alien pleasure doll who glides bewitchingly into the White House for a tryst. She has been invited into the Kennedy Room by horny press secretary Martin Short. Glenn Close, as the starchy first lady (who also plays V.P. in Air Force One) does a sort of Cruella de Reagan who refuses to serve the aliens on her Van Buren china. She is vastly underutilized. Ditto Pam Grier. Michael J. Fox is dispatched early on, while Sarah Jessica Parker and Pierce Brosnan do find romance though their heads and bodies have parted company. Acting honors go to singer Tom Jones playing himself. Is that not unusual?

Review title: You kind of know where Tim Burton was going with it.
Review_body: Tim Burton used his star power to assemble one of the highest power casts you'll see in a mid 90's film. Unfortunately, he doesn't give them that much to do. "Mars Attacks" much like "The Informant!" plays like a joke that doesn't provoke laughter as much as it does a sense of knowing where Burton was going with the film. Basically, he tries to lampoon the 1950's creature feature film particularly "The Day the Earth Stood Still" but an underlying Burton-ian meanspiritness and tendency toward strong violence sucks much of the fun out of the film. The writers provide only a modest amount of fun from which to take leaving Burton to rely on CGI red-spangled speedos on the Martians and the stuntcasting - including Tom Jones wasted by simply playing himself - to push the movie along. Burton cross the spoof line in a few spots and instead simply lifts ideas from much better films particularly Rod Steiger's General Decker a copy of George C Scott General Turgidson from "Dr. Stangelove." The plagiarism serves not as homage but as a sign that you could be watching a much better film. In short, better parody of the same material exists elsewhere.

Although I am a huge fan of Tim Burton, even a talented and innovative director like him turns out a few clunkers. Big Fish (his worst film) had him trying to be something he wasn't and Planet of the Apes is not even worth mentioning. And as for Mars Attacks, well it doesn't rank very highly on my Burton list, but it is a moderately diverting big budget extravaganza. Its just less than the sum of its parts. Not what I've come to expect from Tim Burton.A lot of people were disappointed with Mars Attacks when it came out. Even though its not an altogether bad film. It does occasionally have some inspired scenes of chaos. And the Martian invaders are wonderfully malevolent. But its a little too chaotic for its own good. Too disjointed. Compare it to Gremlins. A similar story about malicious creatures gleefully destroying everything. But Joe Dante managed to keep the slim story going with great energy on his part, not to mention hilariously memorable sight gags and set-pieces. Burton is unable to do the same with Mars Attacks.One thing that must be said for this film is the extraordinary cast Burton has managed to assemble. Not only is it comprised of some of Hollywood's top stars, but even actors in supporting roles just before they hit the big time. As well as Burton faves. (Although Johnny Depp is nowhere to be found!). Even Tom Jones! Which shows you how many people in the world want to work with Tim Burton.I won't go into detail about who we have present. We'd be here all day. And besides, they're so underdeveloped anyway what would be the point? All the actors are just fodder for the Martian attack. Although it is a genuine shocker when you see top names like Michael J Fox and Danny DeVito getting killed after just a few minutes of screen time.Jack Nicholson gets the most scenes, for the simple fact that he's playing not one but two parts. The President James Dale, and Art Land, a developer in Las Vegas. Its an obvious homage to Peter Sellers magnificent showcase in Dr Strangelove. But Nicholson just doesn't have the same range. He's mildly amusing as the befuddled President out of his depth. But the other character is unnecessary and doesn't go anywhere.Pierce Brosnan makes an impression as the pipe smoking scientist certain the Martians are friendly. But he only really opens up in his scenes with Sarah Jessica Parker when they're on board the alien ship. As two severed heads. His a disembodied one. And hers grafted onto a Chihuahua's body.If truth be told the story sags whenever the Martians are not around. With their bulbous brains, bug eyes and maniacal cackle, they're an inspired creation. Clearly loving destroying the Earth, they get some great moments. Like defacing Mount Rushmore and putting their faces on it instead. Blowing up the Taj Mahal while posing in front of it for pictures. And frying Congress!There are lots of great little touches when examining the Martians lifestyle. I love the ray guns they use. They look like something you'd buy from your local toyshop. Their spaceships look like gigantic hubcaps. Their twisted sense of humour extends to blowing up national monuments just for the fun of it. And their infectious laugh reminds me of the aliens from the Cadburys Smash adverts. Without the Martians, Mars Attacks would be a pretty lifeless production.Its just a shame the human cast can't enliven their half. Except for one cast member. Lisa Marie, who delivers a grandstanding scene stealing performance as a Martian disguised as a human girl. Check out her beehive hairstyle designed to hide the giant brain. And her swirly patterned form fitting dress. She doesn't walk. She glides! On a mission to assassinate the President. And gets sidetracked by Martin Short's sex starved Press Secretary. Its a wonderfully witty scene, with a real appealing sense of deadpan humour. And Lisa Marie carries it all off without uttering a single syllable. If only the rest of Mars Attacks had some of the same inspiration.Its not all Tim Burton's fault. The film originated from a set of bubblegum cards. And those striking images of decimation and devastation doesn't provide much in the way of plot. The solution to stopping the Martians is a bit odd, but it fits in with classic B-movie clichés.But overall, Mars Attacks is a disappointment. Its a bloated, over-inflated production with too many cast members. You're actually grateful when the Martians start blowing people away, because it shortens the cast list and tightens the focus. But its still an overlong and painfully slow film at times. A minor entry in Tim Burton's otherwise excellent body of work.

This is a dark comedy, science fiction. Plenty of humor and dark humor and Hollywood's A list was lining up to be shot down by these odd looking aliens. Why don't they have lips? Pierce Brosnan was the brilliant as the Scientist that thinks he can deduce what the aliens are like, but really is completely in the dark. In fact the whole cast is great in this knock out comedy that may be alittle too dark for some and many thought it was like ID4, but it's not like ID4, it's a comedy. It was suppose to be silly, and goofy. The effects were great. Cool, if strange looking aliens, the ships look great. It mainly mirrors "EARTH VS. THE FLYING SAUCERS" in many of the major plot points. So if you've seen EARTH VS. THE FLYING SAUCERS, then you know what basically will happen. But that doesn't spoil the experience. It's a cool movie, with lots of fun to be have. It's underrated and deserves more then it got. I give it...9 STARS

I'd say this is Burton's worst film, even worse than Planet of the Apes, which I actually think is kinda underrated. I read a quote from Ebert regarding this film which I think is quite true, something to the effect that his previous film, Ed Wood, was a tribute to the man, while this film is a tribute to the terrible films he made. He also said it's not good enough or bad enough to be a true tribute, it's just sorta mediocre. And I agree. There are spots of dark comedic brilliance (pretty much anything to do with the Martians), but also some truly terrible moments (most of the human characters and their inane subplots). The whole aspect of the Martians is terrifically executed, from the classic flying saucers to the 'ack ack' to their means of defeat. But the human cast is so universally terrible that it really drags the film down. Really only Jack Nicholson and Pierce Brosnan seem to understand the type of film that is being made; everyone else takes the whole thing so seriously. The subplot with Lukas Haas and his grandmother is unwatchable, the black family is laughable, and the Vegas stuff is cringe-worthy. Though it's a homage to the classic '50s B-movies, it is at once both better than and worse than those films, making for a very uneven and disappointing product.

A massive spoof on 50's style alien horror flicks in general and "Plan 9" in particular. There are innumerable references to this film in "Mars Attacks", and no wonder - after having made "Ed Wood" just a couple of years before, Tim Burton no doubt wanted to explore the genre further. I know this film isn't very popular, but I think it is hilarious and has just the right mix: one part old horror in hindsight and three parts 90's effects. If one loves old and awful horror pictures, Tim Burton is the man, because he sure does too.

Review title: It's highly unusual - top of the line
Review_body: It is with a heavy heart that I admit "Mars Attacks" will buy Tim Burton forgiveness for all the bullshit he has shot. It will wash him clean of the sin that is "Big Fish" and the sacrilege of his remake of "Planet of the Apes". Comics and video games have long become household treasure troves for Hollywood plot scouts, but trading cards? Only Burton could pull it off, aided by an all-star cast if there ever was one: Pierce Brosnan and Sarah Jessica Parker as doomed lovers, Annette Bening as a showgirl, Danny DeVito as a gambler, Glen Close as the first lady, Natalie Portman as the first daughter and, looming at superhuman size, Jack Nicholson in the iconic double role of casino mobster and US president. Many a beta male has posed as the president on the silver screen. Pansies, step aside and make way for James Dale. He fails, but admirably so, going down like a true predator, survived only by that biggest of cats. I never tire of the final scene, a tableau of tranquility in the wake of terrible turmoil and near-extinction. Escaped from his home turf of Las Vegas, Nevada, Tom Jones launches into his trademark tune "It's not unusual" as wild animals flock to him, San Franciscan style. He *is* the tiger after all.

Review title: Ack!! Ack!! Ack!! That's Martian for, "It's a Sci-Fi Classic" !
Review_body: Tim Burton's MARS ATTACKS! is the funniest and greatest acted Sci-Fi film in history! A masterpiece of comedy, only problem is, most people never got it. The film played a week when first released & quickly became a "cult" favorite.The real scene stealers are the Martians themselves...ack...ack...ack...ack. They are the coolest green meanies in the galaxy. And what a demented sense of humor they have! As for the "human" cast, Jack Nicholson is great as usual in dual roles ala Peter Sellers. But, it's academy award winner Rod Steiger as General Decker who captures the spotlight. "Attack! Attack! Attack!" screams Steiger and it's a laugh-attack which follows.In the films greatest scene, Jim Brown as a former heavyweight boxing champion goes punch-for-punch with the Martian champ. It's an awesome scene....capturing not only humor, but the American fighting spirit. In the words of the Martian minister, " Ack...Ack....Ack....Ack!!!!

Review title: Lots of Celebrities but Little Else
Review_body: Tim Burton is great at making movies look like cartoons. I remember when this film was coming out it had a great looking trailer with a cavalcade of stars. How could you lose? For instance the brilliance of casting Rod Steiger as the mad general (patterned after George C Scott in "Dr. Strangelove"). In the trailer he goes "Annihilate! Annihilate!" Very funny. But when you watch the movie, you realise that was all they had for his character. The script is a cut and paste of a bunch of ideas that maybe would have worked as a series of short skits, but for a feature length film, these flimsy characters run out of depth (and interest) long before the film is over.The film of course wants to be a comedy, but starts completely on the wrong foot by depicting a herd of cattle on fire. Frankly this is a horrible and unsympathetic way to open a film, by watching these innocent animals die a grisly death. The first act introduces the large array of characters across the country, as well as the White House. Jack Nicholson as the president is one of the best things in the film, but is diminished by Nicholson also playing a cliché business tycoon who shoots from the hip. The best thing by far is the appropriately superficial TV show personalities played by Michael J. Fox and Sarah Jessica Parker. Their dialogue and story arc is engaging, especially when Pierce Brosnan shows up as that archetypical 50s scientist who always had the answers in the old Sci-Fi movies that this film is based on.Otherwise there is little else to tolerate. The exposition of the dozens and dozens of characters is dull. The editing is lifeless. The decision to include certain scenes, especially the Vegas scenes, seem more obligatory because it features a movie star. My guess is that many of these recognizable faces agreed to do this film for less than their regular salary because it looked like a fun project. But I found almost all the scenes with these memorable faces quite dull. They say or do something somewhat offbeat, but not in any engaging way. For the most part the pay-off in exchange for the amount of time invested in them is not worth it.The two kids whose parents are a bus driver and a Vegas hotel employee. The trailer park family whose son is a gun nut. The grandma in the nursing home. The new age flake. And because, hey, it's Tom Jones and Danny Devito. Both of these people pop into the film in the third act out of nowhere. Devito is given nothing to do otherwise than basically mug for the camera and say "How are ya!"Seemingly a spoof of "Independence Day", I'm sure the reason is that the script writers for both films went the obvious route and focused on how the government along with the first family would respond to an alien invasion. Many side stories with even more side characters are invented to throw in another interesting visual. As for the special effects they went for quantity over quality. On the other hand, because it's a very cartoonish movie, it's almost appropriate that the effects look shiny and plastic. It also incorporates the old fashioned stop motion animation. Again, making this more of a cartoon than a reality based film.But a bunch of goofy imagery with one-note jokes doesn't make a good comedy on the whole.The same goes with the big twist at the end, the accidental discovery that easily kills all the martians. It reminds me of the stupid twist at the end of "Signs". Goofy, but not a knee slapper. Worst for the wear is the cowboy talkin' entrepreneur played by Jack Nicholson. I'm sure he was having fun depicting this showboating businessman, but it all just falls flat and has very little to do with anything. This includes the big setup of a new hotel being built in Vegas, where it is more than obvious the footage is of an actual implosion of an old Vegas tower. Then there is a needless visit to a Vegas sign junkyard. It looks cool but means nothing. Also, for a comedy, there are very graphic and disturbing scenes of people being incinerated. When I saw this in theatre when it first came out, I thought about how much potential this movie could have had with a real story and more engaging dialogue.

I first watched Mars Attacks! Along with my brother. I was too much scared after watching it. After years, when I watched it again I thought how much bad this movie was. Less dramatic, more focus on comedy and cheap special effects.After I watched it now, I came to know that I was wrong. This movie was never intended to be SciFi drama, director wanted to make it SciFi- dark comedy- satire and he did it beautifully. Movie is great entertainment at it's best. Most of the people may not understand the purpose and the message of the film: it acted as a satire on all action and SciFi movies.I was amazed to see that this movie had big name in it's cast like Jack Nicholson, Danny DeVito, Pierce Brosnan, Michael J Fox, Natalie Portman, Jack Black etc. The special effects were also a funny part, because some of them are very well achieved and some of them are really cheesy; that's their purpose.Overall, Mars Attacks! Is one of those films that you have to see for yourself, and ultimately evaluate.

I borrowed this from a friend because I've really been getting into Tim Burton lately and want to try to see all of his films. I expected this one to be kind of a rotten egg because of the rating on IMDb and just the whole premise of the film. I was wrong, this movie is a hilarious and action packed load of fun.Tim Burton does another great job directing and has a star filled cast. Everyone is awesome, especially Jack Nicholson, and Lukas Haas. I usually hate CGI a lot but the cheesy CGI in this film added to the cartoony feel and made it that much more fun. The story is ridiculous and bizarre but awesome nonetheless. I also thought the humor was spot on. This is a new favorite.See this movie if you Sci-Fi/Comedy. It's a must!

Hilarious, creepy and just the right amount of wacky! Starting life originally as a trading cards series, it's transferred to the big screen through a nice easy plot of aliens invading earth from Mars with high-tech weaponry and a serious attitude! It's so much fun with a great ensemble star cast including Jack Nicholson in not one but two roles, one of which is the President... that's all you need in a film! Glenn Close, Danny DeVito, Sarah Jessica Parker, Pam Grier, Martin Short, Michael J. Fox and even Tom Jones are all in for the ride as well as some early appearances from Natalie Portman and Jack Black! There are elements of horror as well as the deep homage to science fiction which show themselves in fantastically twisted moments including the alien abduction and splicing of Parker's head onto a dog's body and a certain thumb chewing off by a Martian (Lisa Marie). Tim's ultimate science-fiction film and what a keeper it is

Review title: Totally wild send up of alien invasion films. A winner
Review_body: The acting is somewhat over the top, it is over cast with big name stars, and the death scenes during the attacks may be a bit gruesome, but this satire of films like "Independence Day" and others is pure genius. The ironic touches, such as the wold being save, by Slim Whitman music, of all things is great. And once again Tim Burton gets to kill off Jack Nicholson. (See Batman, also directed by Burton.) If you are a collector their is no doubt that this film belongs in your library. List it as Science Fiction, list it as a comedy, but most of all list it as fun. Where else would you find Michael J. Fox, Rod Steiger, Jack Nicholson, Glen Close, Pierce Brosnan, and a very young Natilie Portman all in one film?

Review title: A great movie with a twist
Review_body: Mars Attacks is shot beautifully!!! A wonderful cast and storyline!!! It's hysterical throughout the film, it has love, thrilling moments!!! Excellent movie to watch!!! A++ Film.

For people who don't like this film because it's "too corny", they are missing the point. It's supposed to be corny. There's movies that are bad in the sense that there was no thought or effort into them, and there are movies that are intentionally bad, meaning the style is supposed to be all in good fun. This is the latter. Even for a movie that's "intentionally bad", it's still pretty good. I was laughing the whole time. There were a few plot holes here and there, and things that seemed like they were setting up for a payoff, but never did. Despite these problems, I still enjoyed myself. The Martians' design and language were unique, the story was enjoyable, and the actors seemed like they enjoyed themselves. The score was also really good. I may go back and listen to the soundtrack with how epic the score was. Honestly, the score had more effort put into it than there needed to be. The ending was a bit silly and just felt like "We need to end this, so let's end it as soon as possible" and was honestly a bit of a cop out. There are some questions I still have about things left unexplained. Even with these factors, it's still worth a watch just for a fun time. See it and enjoy yourself.
Grade: B 8/10 3.5/5 stars

Review title: Campy alien invasion is a hoot
Review_body: Mars Attacks! (1996) Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Bening, Pierce Brosnan, Sarah Jessica Parker, Martin Short, Jim Brown, Pam Grier, Michael J. Fox, Danny DeVito, Lukas Haas, Sylvia Sidney, Rod Steiger, Paul Winfield, Natalie Portman, Tom Jones, Joe Don Baker, D: Tim Burton. Schlocky parody/homage to '50s alien-invasion inspired loosely by a series of bubble gum trading cards. U.S. President Nicholson is optimistic when an army of martin flying saucers are found hovering around the Earth, but everyone has a different response, until they are greeted in Nevada and turn out to be nasty predators who want to wipe out the population! Cartoonish special effects and animation (of the martians) are good since the movie is a live-action cartoon, but while campy and a hoot, it feels self-satisfied and Burton bites off more than he can chew with the big-name cast. 107 min., rated PG-13. ** ½

At last, an American movie shows the president and the first lady as dumb!  It also destroys American institutions like country music, Las Vegas and military ideology. I love Tim Burton!  This is subversive sense of humor.  Colors are greats and we all love all those wonderful martians who kills everything stupid in American society. And it's so great to see Sylvia Sidney (I'm a fan since 1930's "Dead end".  Long live Tim Burton!

Review title: mean spirit and bad script, only occasionally funny
Review_body: Tim Burton's weakest film, let down by a one-note script, a lack of ideas with real substance and an air of mean-spiritedness. Even his usual brilliant visual sense has deserted him here. Jack Nicholson is very disappointing in two unfunny roles, Glenn Close and Danny DeVito are completely wasted and there is no character whom one can focus on and thus empathise with. That said, there are some very funny moments and the Martians themselves are great; Jim Brown, the divine Pam Grier and Rod Steiger turn in excellent supporting performances (although there is not enough of any of them) and Lukas Haas and Sylvia Sydney provide welcome warmth and humanity: no wonder it is them that save the world.By the way - if you've ever wondered if Tom Jones can act, he can't!

Review title: Achieves it's goal, but that doesn't make it good
Review_body:
"Mars Attacks" clearly sets out to spoof old science-fiction B-movies (and maybe some recent SF B-movies too) and certainly succeeds: the plot is corny and full of holes, the acting is often quite horrible in spite of the all-star cast, the special effects look bad, and the way in which the aliens are defeated is laughable. It's just that Mars Attacks has all of these flaws on purpose, instead of many other movies, where the people that made them actually were serious about what they were doing but just to inept to do it right (e.g. "Independence Day", "Battlefield Earth")The big problem is that Mars Attacks is still a pretty lame movie. Yes, it's bad on purpose, but it's still bad. There are some indeniable funny scenes, but there aren't enough of them to make up for the load of utterly unnecessary and boring scenes that introduce people for the sole purpose of having them killed three scenes later and for the presence of Tom Jones, who should stay as far away from making movies as possible. 
All in all, Tim Burton certainly knew what he was doing when he made this movie: spoofing bad SF movies. Unfortunately, "Mars Attacks" is almost just as bad as the movies it's spoofing. ** out of **** stars

Mars Attacks! scared the bejeezus out of me as a kid but now I understand it. This isn't particularly a kid film even though it looks like it could be one.Special effects are intentionally cheesy with director Tim Burton specifying a claymation look to the CGI martians and a cheap, nostalgic Ed Wood look to their aluminum flying saucers. Cheesy would suggest campy but this film is far from wanting to be wholesome or politically correct. It stars Jack Nicholson as both U.S. President and alcoholic cowboy real estate tycoon and that should tell you something about the wild card and razor sharp mood of the film.
