This film is anarchic, demented, but with its own sense of gleeful and camp fun, much like Nicholson's Joker in the Tim Burton Batman films.Mars Attacks supports a perhaps bloated all-star cast, from Pierce Brosnan and Glen Close to a young Natalie Portman portraying the President's daughter in a slightly wry Leon the Professional sidekick way. Even a rising Jack Black stars. The star wattage is a bit at odds with the very non-mainstream appeal and message the film turned out to have. But most all meet a wicked end, and that adds to the anarchic bent of this over-budget financial flop and eventual cult favorite.I like this film and give it a high 9/10 because it is very good at being exactly what it wants to be, which isn't what most people thought it would be. Some say the film is mean spirited but I think it's about as destructive as a toddler building up a tower of blocks and then enjoying it as he blasts it down. The martians in this film are lethal but wicked funny and they tear down everything that you get the sense was ineffectual anyway. The film is pretty anti-establishment but most pointedly anti-mainstream and that message probably did come across in a brutal but not really vicious way.The film still celebrates the underdog and keeps alive the most caring nobodies to reign in the destructive martians. Tim Burton is present in both the martians and the underdog this time, and the film retains a spark of anti-hero charm while also asking you to sit back while many of your favorite actors and actresses get ironically decimated.If you are also the toddler who liked smashing your tower of blocks, then I think you will find something to like in this high budget wish-fulfillment fantasy. And it is satisfying for what it offers, even though sometimes the plot can be somewhat distracted. But just know this is Tim Burton on spite, and you should probably be in the mood for a satisfying kind of to-heck-with-everything destructive spite in order to enjoy this film. This is comedy-horror and high on the horror, but sometimes we need that.

Only a filmmaker like Tim Burton could make a movie so outrageous and wacky, but at the same time so clever and intelligent. The director got his inspiration for this spoof (not in the AIRPLANE!-style, fortunately; this movie is more subtle than that) of cheesy 50's sci-fi movies from a trading card series which showed weird-looking aliens destroying the Earth with strange weapons, and turned into a twisted and wildly entertaining movie, that's definitely not everyone's cup of tea. Special effects are great; you can't really tell when something's real of fake, hand-made or computer-generated. And what a cast!

I am amazed everytime I watch this film at how original and funny it is. It is guaranteed to put off some viewers, but those who get the joke that is this film will get a big kick out of it. It is a truly hilarious film, but the laughs are not always straightforward. Some scenes are truly elaborate and require repeated viewings to be appreciated. The film has an enormous ensemble cast of Hollywood stars. It's a funny thing to note that everyone gets killed except Tom Jones and Annette Bening. This is really a gutsy film if I ever saw one. The president actually gets killed here! The dog dies too, as does the typical patriotic family trying to be heroic and defend their home. What a complete hoot this film is. How it ever got made, I will never know. It wasn't likely to be a success because it wasn't a typically patriotic blockbuster, it was expensive, and in the end it wasn't a success. It was a terrible flop, which illustrates that Americans really will never be able to laugh at themselves. It's hard to believe that Tim Burton is an american at all. This is one of the most unusual films you'll ever see. It has sophisticated humor and an all-star cast. That's a pretty rare combination. Miss at your own peril...

Review title: if you totally hated Independence Day, you'll love this!
Review_body: i am one of those ID4-haters and, i must admit that this i really like Mars Attacks!. Director Burton must have seen it just before making this. It is a perfect parody on modern day aliens-take-over-the-world-and-USA-saves-the-day movies. Jack Nicholson is definitely having a great time playing the President and alcoholic Art Land (he's the funniest character in this film!). He's intentionally being very serious and very funny at the same time. It's really funny that Tim Burton got all those famous actors to play in his movie. All their characters are so wonderfully useless. Especially Danny DeVito as the gambler and Tom Jones as himself.I know that this movie isn't going to win any awards, but it is really funny, if you get the weird sense of humor. But that's only if you get it!

One movie I love because it's very funny and well filmed, but parts of the story are dumb (especially the ending. It just stops) is Mars Attacks! A lot of fun and my second favorite Burton behind Ed Wood.

Wilfully silly sci-fi pastiche that takes the paranoid excesses of fifties sci-fi schlockers as a starting point and simply adds a twist of parody. The plot: Mars Attacks! Simple as. Well, there's a little more to it than that, obviously, but to say too much would be to give the game away for the eight sci-fi nerds out there yet to see this flick. (Don't get cross, nerds, I'm one of you, too.) The comedy angle is a hit and miss affair, some of it laugh out loud funny, some of it misfiring spectacularly, particularly the sequences involving Brosnan, not a man put on this Earth to bring the gift of laughter. Nor Tom Jones, for that matter. Indeed, two or three of the best lines go to the old Nan character, a wonderfully dry performance by Sylvia Sidney as the loopy old dear, giggling with senility as chaos reigns supreme around her. The best moment in the movie is her standout scene: As the Martians turn their ray guns on the members of the US Congress, we cut to her watching on TV, laughing riotously as she proclaims "They blew up Congress!" I did chuckle at that bit. Burton deftly handles the CGI heavy action sequences, but it is Danny Elfman's wonderfully evocative score that truly shines here, bringing to mind perfectly late night TV fodder such as The Thing From Another World and The Day the Earth Stood Still. Not Burton's best movie by a country mile, this is still an entertaining enough movie in its own right.

Review title: Brilliant! This Is Filmmaking At Its Finest.
Review_body: Martians invade the Earth, and those in charge of the US government and military are completely incompetent boobs. Meanwhile some really weird things happen to some of the main characters. The Earthlings try to reason with the bug-eyed space devils. But in the end the it is not military technology nor government diplomacy that saves the day, leading to one of the strangest, yet funniest movie finales ever. Watch it!

Review title: "Little people, why can't we all just get along?"
Review_body: Tim Burton attempted to smush every single 1950s cheesy science fiction alien movie that ever existed into this film, Mars Attacks. Bug-eyed martians fly from Mars to Earth, and after that long journey, they use their phasers to evaporate members of the US Army who was at the welcoming ceremony. Thus begins the War of the worl.... err... let's go with War Between Man and Non-Men, and encompasses the entire movie. In between, big time stars show up, then are killed or at least have their heads put into a jar. Among the who's who of Hollywood in the film are: Michael J. Fox as a swarmy newscaster, Sarah Jessica Parker as a talk show host, Annette Benning as an alien crazed woman of some means, Jim Brown as a big black man, Jack Black as a dopey army man, Pierce Brosnan as a scientist, Martin Short as the President's press secretary, Glenn Close as the first lady, and Jack Nicholson as the President of the United States. So to sum it up, most of the stars play themselves in the film, including Tom Jones, who plays Tome Jones. Nicholson as the president is a funny choice and one part of originally creativity that I enjoyed in the film. The part I didn't like is how the aliens were defeated, by way of bad music, causing their brains to explode. It's kind of amusing at first, but the laughter falls off and we just hope the movie ends. The jokes, for the most part, are in the first half of the movie and tend to play off of what we know about the actors playing certain roles, and less off of the 50s movies that inspired the movie to begin with. I do not know why more related to the 50s was not used, I guess Burton didn't trust his material that much. Enjoyable to a point, Mars Attacks ends up being a disappointing homage to the science fiction films of the 50s.

Review title: Planet Earth is attacked by crazed Martians.
Review_body: Adsurdity done to perfection. Either you are a fan of Tim Burton or not, but even those who are not could very well find this movie entertaining as there is a lot going on than just Mars attacking Earth. And what makes it so are all the little details, especially in the scenes with only the Martians. (Sidebar here: Check out Nathan Archer's book, Mars Attacks: Martian Deathtrap, for a fun read and more examples of how life as a Martian is not much different than life as a human.) We get to see that even in the Martian "world" there are slackers who are asleep at the control panel. The story is simple and moves along quickly, and though there are a lot of actors (human), it is easy to keep track of who is who and their respective characters and personalities. We have, of course, your basic military personnel with the mindset of "shoot first and ask questions later." There is also the scientific community that firmly states that there is no need to think that 1000s of spaceships surrounding the planet could mean the Martians are getting ready to attack, and even keep to this mindset after a few attacks occur. And of course a president who has to ask his wife what to do, even though her goal in life is to replace all that chintz with watered silk. The first meeting with the Marians, of course, ends in disaster, as this is the overall plan of the Martians. We find out that the Marians have a sick, though funny, sense of humor and are able to lead the humans on with talks of misunderstandings numerous times. And of course who cannot love the final scenes where, by accident, our intrepid hero, played by Haas, finds the only way to kill the Martians. I mean, whose head would not explode after hearing Slim Whitman singing Indian Love Call? Good special F/X, a lot of funny scenes and good lines, and a cast filled with good actors, both human and Martian.

One thing I like a lot about this movie is that you never know when someone is going to die or live. It doesn't matter how big the star is - some get killed off right in the first attack. And it just sort of keeps you guessing who is going to be the Martians' next victim. And just when you think someone is going to make it to the end - BAM! He or she is gone as well. For once, Hollywood isn't afraid of bumping off its stars early in a movie, and this movie has lots of them

Review title: A real blast but somehow missing the golden touch - 74%
Review_body: At last! Another one of those movies I've waited years to see, I can finally cross this off my list. But for some reason, I'm not lighting fireworks and dancing around a bonfire. Maybe I was expecting too much - after all, it has all the big-name stars you could ever want and one of my favourite directors in the big chair, Tim Burton. By taking a well-worn genre and infusing it with his typically dark vision, Burton has fashioned a quirky and entertaining sci-fi blast that ticks every cliché you could imagine. But whether it's a dark fable on resisting the American Dream or simply an excuse to zap recognisable faces, this is one film that dares to be different from every other alien film and to be frank, that's as good a reason as any to celebrate.As the Hubble telescope spots hundreds of flying saucer-shaped things flying over from Mars, President James Dale (Jack Nicholson) is torn between welcoming the alien visitors and blowing them out of the sky. Convinced by Professor Kessler (Pierce Brosnan) that they mean us no harm, President Dale addresses the nation on this historic moment. But for some, there are more important things to deal with. Nathalie Lake (Sarah Jessica Parker) sees the aliens as an opportunity for a great talk show, tycoon Art Land (Nicholson again) isn't going to let the aliens ruin him opening his new casino and journalist Jason Stone (Michael J Fox) senses the scoop of the century. Sadly, these aliens have only two things on their massive minds - total annihilation of the Earth and having some fun while they're at it.In all the mayhem, it's easy to lose track of who is doing what and why with the exception of the aliens themselves. Truth be told, the aliens get the biggest laughs - not only do they look fabulous but they have the funniest scenes such as taking photos of themselves in front of the exploding Taj Mahal or the slightly creepy undercover Martian girl (Lisa Marie) with White House Press Secretary Jerry Ross (Martin Short). The look of the film is quite unique in a way I unexpected, like Burton's "reimagining" of "Charlie And The Chocolate Factory" but surprisingly, it doesn't detract too much from the movie as a whole. The cast, by contrast, do exactly that - each actor feels like they're actually playing themselves but the only one who is isn't an actor at all. Tom Jones' appearance in the second half is as ridiculous as it is sublime but sadly, all too brief. But as each star wrestles for screen time, I couldn't help thinking it was repeating the same mistake that "Ocean's Twelve" did. Simply throwing big name actors at the screen isn't enough to make a movie entertaining which is why the aliens are the true stars of "Mars Attacks!".It sounds like I've got a bit of a downer on this movie but I really haven't. I enjoyed the sheer sense of fun, despite scores of people being reduced to coloured skeletons and their component atoms. It's much more fun than the recent "War Of The Worlds" remake as well as being a delightful poke in the eye for overly patriotic disaster flicks like "Independence Day" or "The Day After Tomorrow". For that, I can only applaud Burton for crafting a wonderfully silly alien movie with just enough darkness to keep kids behind the sofa. It's like that classic British sci-fi series "Dr Who" - full of special effects and deadly alien weapons but with a cheeky glint in its eye to tell you not to worry too much. "Mars Attacks!" isn't Burton's best film and neither will it appeal to everyone - it's just too weird - but it's still worth seeking out if you haven't seen it yet. Just make sure you don't wait 13 years before watching it as you'll probably be let down.

Review title: One of the greatest comedies ever made!
Review_body: It seems that everyone who was involved in that movie is embarrassed about it. Who knows why!Mars Attacks! is a smart movie with delicate humour that combines B movie aesthetics with a realistic view of today's society. The aliens are hilarious and the cast is absolutely cream of the crop. To me this movie along with Ed Wood are Burton's best efforts yet and they both probably indicate where he comes from.If you are looking for some intelligent humour, look no further. If you enjoyed Scary Movie, avoid Mars Attacks! please...10/10

Tim Burton is a strange director.  I listened to many comments from Actors and others that say he's a genius, but unfortunately I've never noticed. All his films are the same (how about trying something different for once). Both Edward Scissorhands and Batman were bad, but this is even worse.None of the comedy works in this film.  The occasional comment on American culture is so unsubtle it doesn't work at all.Completely pointless waste of time of a movie, avoid it at all costs.God knows why but I'm sure some rich producer will give this talentless director another pile of cash to create yet another bizarre self-indulgent fantasy.  Give it to someone else please.

Review title: better pf edwars the scissor hans.
Review_body: 6.2 ARISE THE VOTE beautiful film. As to the usual one, the usual negative comments which talk about a classical film some years 80 which everyone does not like it to the nostalgic ones are met.Sure Heros that this film had to have a judgment in this site. In fact reviewers' good part has put a high vote to the previous episodes. Because this contrast? I know the reason. Since assumptive reviewers' good part favorably sees the past and as the past is "better" than the present they have given several credit to the preceding episodes being still the last episode more explosive and spectacular. At this point should reject also the old episodes but there are here two weights and two measure.In fact also cinema masterpieces have been criticized and denigrated. Good part some reviewers of this site belong to the very bad reviewers. Better think separately with its head.

GOOD INTERESTING STORY THAT IS FUN AND PRETTY EASY TO FOLLOW = 1 StarMEMORABLE DIALOGUE = 0 StarsFEEL A PULL TO WATCH IT AGAIN = 1/2 StarMUSIC OR SCORE STANDS OUT = 1 StarNO NOTICEABLE PLOT HOLES = 0 StarsSTORY GETS RESOLVED OR FEELS COMPLETE IN SOME WAY = 1 StarI PERSONALLY LIKE OR FEEL A CONNECTION TO THIS STORY = 1 StarMEMORABLE OR LIKABLE CHARACTERS = 1 StarMOST THINGS ABOUT THE STORY COULD ACTUALLY HAPPEN OR ARE BELIEVABLE = 1/2 StarSTORY ISN'T BORING OR REPETITIVE =
0 StarsThere is no doubt that this movie is well done and literally has a full star cast. It's thrilling and exiting thinking about finding another living intelligent race. Although this movie is really well done and interesting, just over halfway through I feel like it gets repetitive and I'm just watching the same action take place over and over. It's a great watch with great acting! Just repetitive for me.

Review title: This is where Independence Day is put to shame.
Review_body: As someone stated before, with tremendous accuracy, Mars Attacks! is one of those movies in which you rarely encounter a mid term: either you love it or you hate it.Personally, I have to say that I stand on the "loved it" part. Mars Attacks! is great entertainment at it's best, and Tim Burton did an incredibly good job, as usual. One of the things that seems to bother me the most is that some people may not understand the purpose and the message of the film: it's mission is to spoof all those action and Sci-fi movies that abound on clichés and laughable scenes; in which Independence Day is one clear example. Independence Day is bad, relies too much on SFX, and abuse the audience's sanity, believing us to be fools. This is the idea that Jonathan Gemes (screenwriter) and Tim Burton(director) had in mind.Also one high point of the movie is it's main attraction to it's cast: Box Office names like Jack Nicholson; Glenn Close; Danny DeVito; Pierce Brosnan; Sarah Jessica Parker; Michael J Fox; (th great) Natalie Portman; Lukas Haas; Jack Black; Pam Grier and Annette Bening, all of them come together, representing a part of society and social status that they spoof themselves. The special effects are also a funny part, because some of them are very well achieved and some of them are really cheesy: that's their purpose.Anyway, much more shouldn't be said, since Mars Attacks! is one of those films that you have to see for yourself, and ultimately evaluate. 9 ou of 10

One of the most widely used cliché's of science fiction is the Little Green Men or LGMs. That and several other phrases are used to describe some of the frequently used and rather bad plot devices in science fiction movies. In the case of this movie, even the exaggerations are exaggerated.
It starts with an all-star cast led by Jack Nicholson playing two roles. He plays the president of the United States and a glittery Las Vegas huckster. Among others, Glenn Close is the First Lady, Pierce Brosnan is a perpetual pipe smoking intellectual, Jim Brown is an ex-fighter now working as a Las Vegas gladhander, Martin Short is the White House Press Secretary and Danny DeVito is a loudmouth Vegas gambler. Every single role is deliberately overplayed, you get the impression that the actors really enjoyed hamming it up.
The villains are Martians carrying disintegrator guns and that have green Jell-O for brains. Like the classic tale by H. G. Wells, at first the Martians win all the battles, but eventually the humans discover their fundamental weakness and after that the humans quickly win the war. That weakness is hilarious.
Even though the stakes are the survival of humans on Earth, there is never a truly serious moment in this movie. It is truly impossible to select the one most absurd parody in the movie, there are so many, and all are so overdone.

I laughed quite hard when I saw Mars Attacks. Luckily the producers chose to make it a comedy, because if it was going to be serious it would be funny for them trying to scare you. Anyways...the effects aren't bad...could have been a bit improved but still was ok. Most people would find it funny I think. Although it might bother small kids it's really not that bad. Jam packed with stars such as Pierce Brosman, Jack Nicholson and the list just rolls on and on. Go watch it if you havent yet!96%

What happens when a martian invasion occurs on earth? Absolute terror. No one knows what to do and or say. Even the president(Jack Nicholson) hasn't a clue to what to do. So what do humans do to turn the tables on our feisty little guests? Watch and see.Tim Burton has done another fantastic movie that will have to be added to your collections. I recommend this to adults and children of no more and or less than 7 years old. Sometimes this movie scares people. Mainly younger children in the ages of 3 to 5. Oh and I wouldn't recommend letting your dogs watch it either. For some reason this movie makes them dark.

Review title: A great movie for bad movie lovers
Review_body: It seems like Mars Attacks is Tim Burton's ultimate tribute to Ed Wood's badfilm making. This is a dream come true for MST3K fans: A cheesy sci-fi movie, only with a big budget and people that can actually act. It's creepy in ways I can't describe. Unfortunately is a mistargeted film. An A-movie and B-moviehybrid that pleases neither audience. Definitively not for the mainstream movie lover. Maybe time will tell if this film becomes finally a cult classic of some kind.

What a colossal waste of time and talented actors. I haven't been so bored in a long, long time. There's nothing even remotely funny or interesting going on in this movie...and even what could have been a funny moment regarding one certain musical selection isn't funny either. This is a huge miscalculation on the script-writer and director's part. I was going to blame the bad editing but the movie is < 2 hrs so it's not as though someone let this drivel drag on longer than necessary. If this is supposed to be a spoof, it's a totally wasted, boring effort of one.

Strangely, this purposefully little engaged sci-fi spoof by Tim Burton is more unforgettable than seriously dedicated homage pieces, such as Eight Legged Freaks. Some bad ingredients may be thanks to intentional low-tech, while the others may be due to lack of crafts; the mixture of both keeps the audience guessing if Burton is serious or joking. For example, the ridiculously classic Martian appearance modeled with cheap 3-D technology seems to be well-thought, while the ludicrous political satire may be the result of Burton's poor skill in that area. Too many inconsistent and unresolved subplots (e.g., the romance between the heads of Sarah Jessica Parker and Pierce Brosnan in a Martian spaceship) are difficult to judge if they are by design or not.One thing for sure is that the film is successfully bad to satisfy movie fans' demands for bad flicks.

Maybe it was due to the huge success of 'Ed Wood' two years earlier that 'Mars Attacks!' was dissed by the critics and ignored by the public (which is very odd as it is much more commercially viable than the former title). It is also almost as good as 'Ed Wood' which is, for me, Burton's greatest achievement, so far. Tim Burton may have been channeling Ed Wood's spirit when he created this farcical, cheesy comedy about Martians attacking Earth, primarily Las Vegas and Washington, D.C. There is definitely social commentary going on here as we watch the destruction of the sleazy, besequined casinos and the equally sleazy United States Congress in session.This movie is one of Burton's most star-studded and all the actors are funny and clearly enjoying themselves. Jack Nicholson doubles as President of the United States and a high- rolling Texas scum ball out to make a killing in 'Vegas. He is alternately fatuous and stupid in a very convincing manner. Annette Beining shines in a rare comedic role for her as the Texas idiot's new-age-besotted girlfriend. She is extremely funny in this part and plays the dumb blonde to perfection. The jewel in this comedy crown is the late, great Rod Steiger as the sabre-rattling general who comes to one of the most hilarious ends ever in the movies.Martin Short is also a standout as the oily George Stephanopoulos-style White House press secretary who meets and is dispatched by the beautiful, camp Martian Girl played by the ever-delicious Lisa-Marie. Sarah Jessica Parker is perfectly cast as the empty-headed, vain news babe. Her dog, Poppy, a tiny Chihuahua, is a splendid canine actor. Burton excels at casting animal actors in all his movies. And then there is Danny DeVito, in prime condition, giving one of his funniest performances since 'Taxi'.The episodes in Kansas inside the trashy trailers are highlights, with the late Sylvia Sidney stealing every scene she appears in as Gramma, with her stuffed cat in her room at the nursing home and her addiction to Country Western music, music which eventually destroys the Martians by making their heads explode.I can't stop without mentioning the wonderful musical score by Danny Elfman. The f/x team should also be commended for the creation of the funniest space aliens ever, with their bikini underwear and bizarre vanity.This is a very funny movie and recommendable for families. It won't scare the youngsters and will entertain the grownups. Make lots of popcorn and be ready to laugh.

Review title: If you like camp and science fiction, you'll love this film!
Review_body: I am not a big science-fiction fan, nor am I partial to Tim Burton movies, but this one became one of my favorites from both categories within the first 30 minutes. First and foremost, this film is a great example of high camp. It is simultaneously dark-comedy and tongue-in- cheek sarcasmextremely witty, well-timed, and sometimes perfectly subtle.The cast was awesome–it felt like everybody's agent frantically told them, "You need to be in this movie!" And their agents were right! Good thing Kevin Bacon wasn't in this flick, or that famous game would be ruined because it'd be too easy. Not only were the big names present, but they were also performing their asses off. Whether they were nailing a tagline, cheesing a smug smile, conveying emotion through a subtle non-verbal cue, or purposefully over-acting, these actors brilliantly nailed their roles, and brought a great script to life. One scene involving Pam Grier, Ray J, Brandon Hammond, and a bus had me cracking up and cheering, in particular. By the way, I usually do not find Parker attractive, but I gotta admit she was pretty friggin' smokin' in this movienot hotter than Christina Applegate, though, whom I only recognized after staring at the screen and wondering, "Who is that fine-ass chick?"And let's not forget the one area of this movie in which I expected Burton to deliver most: the aliens. Well, Burton came through even better than expected. The CGI was creative, scary, repulsive, ridiculous, and funny. At one point, I wondered whether it was treason to cheer for the aliens.Honestly, I think I didn't rate this flick higher only because I'm not a big fan of the science-fiction genre, so I probably wouldn't watch it more than once, but if you're a science-fiction lover, you might consider this movie a must-own. I definitely think everyone should make the time to watch it at least once, though.

Review title: Meeting the Other as an horror-surrealist party
Review_body: "Mars attacks!" breaks the happy situations of other sci-fi movies that saw in this meeting a message of brotherhood and similarity beyond the phsicycal and cultural differences. Here human beings think that aliens, because of their incredible intelligence, have necessarily to be intelligent, and so pacific. This spilbergianan point of view is rapidly brokenn: the optimist position of human beings (too static and without dialogues with empirical world), makes the aliens act easily and menage to kill a lot of people, with mad actions that make them similar to Gremlins.A negative role is play by graphics, that's a little bit poor and unrealistic. But this movie have to be watched as a funny entertainment that reveals interesting reflections on meeting aliens, through parody and irony, but without a real deepening of the problems. His nature not so burtonian (it's not gothic or halloweenian) and his a little weak plot makes the movie not a masterpiece; but it can be watched as something interesting for anarchical destruction that breaks all human expectations, that are built by other movies' conceptions.

Review title: The Good, the Bad and the Nasty
Review_body: A few of us like grade B horror and sci-fi movies that come on late at night, we're the crowd that watches Mystery Science Theater 3000 and Elvira. This is Tim Burton's audience which is small compared to the mega following of Star Wars and Titanic. No wonder Mars Attacks! bombed at the box office but not surprisingly it instantly became a TV cult classic. Burton is extremely talented (the beginning of Mars Attacks with its great special effects, editing, music and camera work is masterful film making) but he chooses not to make mainstream commercial movies (except for Batman where he knuckled under to Warner Brothers) and yet his films are just popular enough to continue his career. Why do many people dislike Mars Attacks!? Along with Burton's love for old B horror and Sci-fi movies is his dislike for the lifestyle and taste of the mainstream public. Mars Attacks! on the surface is another Independence Day but underneath they are completely different movies. While Independence Day is wrapped in the flag and God Bless America, Mars Attacks! gives it the finger. Lots of characters are not shown in a favorable light in Mars Attacks! to put it mildly; the President, his First Lady and press secretary, military officers, scientists, TV reporters, businessmen, lawyers, red necks and patriots. Who are our heroes?; two teenagers that don't get along with their parents, an ex heavyweight champion, kids who like video games, a single mother, an air head New Age drunk, a senile grandmother who likes Slim Whitman music and Tom Jones. And this is where I crack up. I know it is wicked, but this crowd of misfits as our saviors is hilarious as we watch Las Vegas Casinos explode and hear a Mariachi band play the Star Spangled Banner. Is there nothing sacred to Tim Burton? Only that weirdoes rule (being one himself I guess this is natural). Every minute of this movie is filled with put downs both subtle and tacky and it is beautifully done. The film score has that right 50's cheesy organ sound but this eventually gives way to the songs of Slim Whitman who is indescribable, the only country western singer with a cult following. Then there are the Martians. The computer graphics are excellent showing them having a jolly time toasting everyone with ray guns especially wiping out America. Oh yes, and they quack like ducks. If you are still reading this, I figure what I've written doesn't make much sense to most of you. Well, I'll just say that I like off beat comedy and Mars Attacks! fits the bill.

Review title: One of the weakest Burton's creations
Review_body: It looks like Tim Burton was contractually obligated to do this film. Everything in it says "hired director". Perhaps Warner Brothers felt he was the one to deliver apt competition to 20th Century Fox's "Independence Day" made the same year. The idea almost backfired: "Mars Attacks!" made the slight profit only thanks to international broadcasting. Maybe Europeans have more taste for Burton's visions than Americans do? Or is it that the joke in this film IS on the Americans? "The greatest nation on Earth" notoriously finds it difficult to laugh at themselves especially when patriotism is mocked. Burton as an author likes to mock about and this would seem to be the subject he'd be at home with.However it doesn't seem he had much control over this particular project. The script is unusually bad for a typical Burton movie. Weak dialog, forced and sparse lines, even the usually good actors have a lot of trouble delivering them convincingly and with good timing. Jokes and gags don't connect. There are way too many characters that don't serve much purpose other than to fill up time. None of them is particularly interesting or likable. There is a completely useless second Nicholson's character and the scenes with him just didn't make sense. Okay, I get it - the fact that Las Vegas' casino owner and the president of the US are played by the same actor should somehow convey that the two have the same mentality - oh, big deal. I don't even want to guess what were Danny DeVito and Tom Jones doing there. The storyline is disjointed and a lot of scenes are illogical or plain stupid.Art design is bad as well. The colors are all over the place, not something you'd expect of a typically monochromatically oriented Burton. He usually uses colors only to emphasize something nasty or sinister. Was this entire film nasty or sinister? Cinematography is also bad to the same end. It is uneven and some colors stand out too much.Special effects are made to look trashy. Okay. But they are also irritating. The perspective, the animation, the composition with footage show total disrespect for physics and put a lot of strain on a human eye and perception. Suspect of disbelief is in overdrive here.The very direction, that was the primary Burton's responsibility, is also uneven. It's fighting with the script, lousy actors' deliveries (not entirely their fault) and uncertainty whether this was supposed to be an action movie, a comedy or a satire. Ultimately it was none of these. It was a mess.Some people will appreciate "Mars Attacks!" as a parody. I know I have back then in 1996. Since then I forgot the films this one was parodying. Some will appreciate it as a satire on American society and I'm okay with that. But that satire was rather shallow and predictable and it didn't really hit where it hurts. Nobody will appreciate this as an action movie. It was not.The die-hard Burton's fans will argue that all of the things in it were deliberately put there, that it was an homage to 50's trash sci-fis, that there is a lot of subtle symbolism to be found in it and that Tim Burton knew what he was doing as he (usually) does.I'd say he just had a really, really bad day at work. He was gambling with a high budget production, and almost lost. The American audience was right this time and the Europeans saved the film for no good reason.

This lovingly created 50's movie homage by Tim Burton is one of my favourite sci-fi comedies. Since I regularly watch these kinds of movies, for example the work of late and great Ed Wood, I know the settings and the plot quite well, and most of the things in Mars Attacks! are spot on.The cast is truly remarkable too. Never has so many actors fought for so little screen time without over-acting. Jack Nicholsson almost manages to steal the show with his two characters, but there are lots of other actors doing various roles, ranging from Pierce Brosnan as the sophisticated scientist(smoking a pipe!), Danny de Vito as a lawyer, Tom Jones as himself, Natalie Portman, Tim Burton's girlfriend Lisa Marie, Glenn Close, Michael J Fox(yay!) and quite a few others I've missed.The effects are cheesy but well-made. Multi-coloured skeletons from multicoloured alien ray-gun blasts, flying saucers which are truly that(flying saucers), and lot's of pyrotechnics.The aliens are really cool and come straight out of one of the cultiest of all 50's movies(I've sadly forgotten the title). Huge brains, staring eyes, and a sadistic sense of humour.I recommend this movie to anyone who likes the cheesiness of old-time sci-fi and can appreciate Tim Burton's love for it. 10/10

I hated this. Its a movie you either like this or you hate it. Its too silly. Tom Jones is its only Bright Spot. What a total waste of money.This film cost a fortune but although the cast are having fun.no one else is.a total turkey.1 out of 10

A few of us like grade B horror and sci-fi movies that come on late at night, we're the crowd that watches Mystery Science Theater 3000 and Elvira. This is Tim Burton's audience which is small compared to the mega following of Star Wars and Titanic. No wonder Mars Attacks! bombed at the box office but not surprisingly it instantly became a TV cult classic. Burton is extremely talented (the beginning of Mars Attacks with its great special effects, editing, music and camera work is masterful film making) but he chooses not to make mainstream commercial movies (except for Batman where he knuckled under to Warner Brothers) and yet his films are just popular enough to continue his career.Why do many people dislike Mars Attacks!? Along with Burton's love for old B horror and Sci-fi movies is his dislike for the lifestyle and taste of the mainstream public. Mars Attacks! on the surface is another Independence Day but underneath they are completely different movies. While Independence Day is wrapped in the flag and God Bless America, Mars Attacks! gives it the finger. Lots of characters are not shown in a favorable light in Mars Attacks! to put it mildly; the President, his First Lady and press secretary, military officers, scientists, TV reporters, businessmen, lawyers, red necks and patriots. Who are our heroes?; two teenagers that don't get along with their parents, an ex heavyweight champion, kids who like video games, a single mother, an air head New Age drunk, a senile grandmother who likes Slim Whitman music and Tom Jones. And this is where I crack up. I know it is wicked, but this crowd of misfits as our saviors is hilarious as we watch Las Vegas Casinos explode and hear a Mariachi band play the Star Spangled Banner.Is there nothing sacred to Tim Burton? Only that weirdos rule (being one himself I guess this is natural). Every minute of this movie is filled with put downs both subtle and tacky and it is beautifully done. The film score has that right 50's cheesy organ sound but this eventually gives way to the songs of Slim Whitman who is indescribable, the only country western singer with a cult following.Then there are the Martians. The computer graphics are excellent showing them having a jolly time toasting everyone with ray guns especially wiping out America. Oh yes, and they quack like ducks.If you are still reading this, I figure what I've written doesn't make much sense to most of you. Well, I'll just say that I like off beat comedy and Mars Attacks! fits the bill.

Up front: I am a Tim Burton fan.  I like think his visual style is among modern American cinema's best, and I enjoy his quirky oddball hero stories. "Mars Attacks" is a mixed bag for me, but I get the jokes.Tim Burton must have been at a point in his career where he just sat back and said to himself: "I want to make a fun movie for me."  If this isn't how it came about, that's how it comes across.  I know enough about the old trading card series to know that he pulled some of the best jokes from them, and the alien's attack on Earth is pretty much just gleeful mischief.  It's the same kind of sadistic enjoyment that a kid would have kid burning ants with a magnifying glass.  I can't believe the number of celebrities that came together for this movie. A lot of cult movie actors, as well as Burton's regular film castings make an appearance in this movie, and the way they overact and overdramatize everything, they seem to be having as much fun as the director.As I said in my header, this is a deliberate "B Movie".  The special effects are cheesy.  The acting is over the top with silly lines.  Everyone in charge doesn't seem that particularly bright, and it's up to a teenage kid to save the world.  The main thing I had an issue with is how they finally stopped the aliens.  One one hand, it was really funny (Kind of reminded me of "Killer Tomatoes").  On the other hand, it seemed to be pulled out of nowhere, and what an odd weapon.  Still, I laughed at the absurdity.It's funny this came out the same year as "ID4".  Intentional or not, it served as an amusing side parody.  Not my favorite of the Burton films, but the impressive cast list and utter silliness makes it worth an occasional watch.

A film so silly it's actually quite good and entertaining! OK, lets be honest the chances of martians coming to Earth looking like that are absolute zero, there's no denying that on close inspection they do look frightening. This reviewing nearly soiled his pants when the martian girl played well by Lisa Marie appeared because she was frightening and you knew just what it was! Many people state that having Tom Jones in the film as himself was a mistake. I disagree, Jones is very good in the role and adds some humour.The ending where Slim Witman's music is playing and the aliens can't stand it is just so damn funny! Overall grade - B

Review title: This movie is a bizarre mess
Review_body: What if Martians invaded for no good reason? I think that's what this means is about I don't really know stuff just kinda happens in this one. I don't regret watching this and I can recommend it but it's by no means good it's just odd.

I agree with Art with the whole "perfect for ID4 haters" since, let's face it, Independence Day, is extremely over rated, and I agree with Robert, for saying you if you didn't like SCTV, stay away.  I loved this movie, it's a great escape from reality, and in a sense, it was supposed to appear to be bad.  If you don't know what I mean, go rent This Island Earth, or another junk 50's movie.  This is a great movie for fans of MST3K, to play with.

Review title: Like a centrefold - big, dumb and empty-headed.
Review_body: I'm loathe to criticise Tim Burton's work as he seems to have so much enthusiasm and passion. He doesn't mind not conforming to audience expectations ( 'Batman' ), or tackling off-beat projects which other directors would avoid ( 'Ed Wood', 'Nightmare before Christmas' etc.). Praise aside, the fact remains that good directors still make some poor films - 'Mars Attacks' is poor at best.The film is a big-budget, effects laden, homage to the Sci-Fi films of the 50's, where Earth was under continual attack from a variety of fiendish aliens. Set in the present day, 'Mars Attacks' follows in comic-book style an invasion by Men-from-Mars, and the resulting chaos this has on a cross-section of stereotyped characters.The effects are excellent, the premise full of potential, and the cast top notch - but the film stumbles to such a degree that its conclusion is met with the same sighs of relief as the 'B' films it is sending up.The cast is impressive to say the least ( rivaling 'A Bridge too Far' which was a similarly empty effort ), but few characters are fleshed out to any degree and roles seem to have been written around whichever star name offered their services - a policy which deals death blows to the script and narrative. Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Michael J. Fox etc. all jump on for the ride but get in each others way and end up as dumb 1-dimensional characters - only Sylvia Sydney manages to put any real meat into her role.The film is reasonable lightweight entertainment, but it promises so much more. Tim Burton has worked hard to get himself into the privileged position where he can indulge his film ideas - if 'Mars Attacks' is the result then success has indeed been a double-edged sword.The resulting film is simply not funny, and the story drags tediously - 'Mars Attacks' fails as a spoof, a comedy, an action film - you name it.

When I first heard about Mars Attacks!, my friends told me that it was a "hilarious comedy" and that I'd love it. Well, after I watched it, I couldn't help asking myself: "what kind of a comedy was that?" Apparently a satire, Mars Attacks! fails due to a bunch of factors, that, taken together, don't help the movie at all.This Burton "comedy" automatically assumes that, because it's a parody, it'll be funny. But it isn't. It's very hard to laugh during the film. A parody won't be funny unless the material is funny. It's not funny to see Jack Nicholson as the President because the role isn't written comically.Jokes are overdone. We see the aliens' ray guns turn people into skeletons. This is funny the FIRST time it happens. But with each recurrence of the supposedly comic weapon, it becomes less and less funny, and just dull. The same applies when the humans learn of a weapon that causes the Martians' brains to explode. It's funny the first time, but soon is used so often that it loses its effect.The plot of the film is just random. I couldn't really find anything purely satirical about it. The way I've been able to decipher it, it asks the question "what if a group of people refuse to be assimilated? What would happen?" But its done unsuccessfully.When it comes to acting, Pierce Brosnan is the only real highlight. Danny DeVito occasionally scores, but not consistently. And Jack Nicholson finds himself in an ineffectual (and very unfunny) double role.But the film does occasionally score when it comes to comedy. Just not consistently and not often enough. Mars Attacks! should've either been a lot better or a lot worse. As it is, it doesn't work.

Review title: The "humor" misses the point and all that's left is tasteless violence.
Review_body: I saw this movie hoping to be entertained. It had good reviews and all, but I saw it and found it revolting. The special effects are too good, the killing is too realistic, and thereby the humor is lost. The movie would, in my eyes, have been much better as a straight cartoon.The story is old-style SF horror, somewhat like "war of the worlds". So far so good. I am sure the script was hilarious, but a realistic massacre (of which there are several) is a realistic massacre. And too much violence doesn't make a good story in any event.Another weakness of the movie is the over-using of stars. The movie is littered by well-known stars, giving us a cavalcade of Hollywood stars being evaporated. This is silly, but not amusing, only a sign of a low-quality movie.The story is very close to "Independence day". They arrived closely after each other, making "Mars attacks" feel like a parody of the former.For the technical quality, I don't give it bottom ratings, but there is little more that is good with it. In particular, it should come with warnings: If you are sensitive, it can bee to much for you. And I don't think I am over-sensitive, I have seen movies like "Predator" and found it great, but "Mars Attacks!" gave me nightmares. Literally!

Now this is truly a great imagination that Tim Burton had made in his whole life.This has every thing a martin should have,a spaceship,ray guns,lasers,etc...This truly showed many funny parts around the earth like in Russia,took a picture when the blasted a building.Or a strike once they took out the wooden things,and Mount Rushmore of famous martins.And very funny of Nathalies' head on her dogs' head.And because of yodeling music the earth his safe.Also the giant robot was really cool-and the giant claws too.Jack Nicholson play real good here-and did two roles,President James Dale and Art Land.Next too the Joker he did just fine in this movie.I also like the funky music that was play for the Martins' theme song.And real good from the ray guns that turn us into red or green skeleton was the bomb.If this was a remake it wont be better like this one.Not even the director Peter Jackson or Steven Spilburg could make this movie even better than it was.

My wife, who is a huge Tim Burton fan despised this movie, where as, I, who hates Tim Burton's movies with a passion, absolutely loved Mars Attacks.The fact that the Martians did not attack Earth to conquer it but to attack it for their own amusement made this movie such a fun ride. My god, they were little pricks, but I respected their execution of their diabolical plan. I enjoyed the fun filled cast and the cartoonish violence. When I saw it in the theater with my wife when it came out, I was laughing my hind parts off while my wife stoically stared at the screen muttering "I hate this movie" every now and then. I did finally come around and found that I really dig "Nightmare Before Christmas" so Tim Burton isn't all that bad.I just watched "Mars Attacks" tonight and yes, the movie holds up and should have gotten a lot more attention than it did when it was released.

Review title: Ridiculous attack, poor film making from Tim Burton
Review_body: I used to love watching this movie when I was a kid. I felt the Martians character was creepy and somehow really fun, I watched it over and over again but never got bored. But after about 15 years and watching it again yesterday, my point of view about 'Mars Attacks!' suddenly change. This is a type of movie that gives different impression if you watched it in 1990s and nowadays. May be in 1996 or few years after, 'Mars Attacks!' is still fine and exceptional for viewers but it's boring and silly when viewers watch these days. In other words, this movie gets old for young generation.The storyline itself is more like B-movie. It has no heart and chemistry between their entire casts. I have no idea what was Tim Burton purpose by directing this poor movie. It's one of his worst movie I've ever seen, even worse than 'Dark Shadows'. The only thing that could save this movie is their casts. They didn't act remarkably though but it's fun to see star like Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Annette Benning, Pierce Brosnan, Danny De Vito and Michael J. Fox in a movie. And don't forget, it also had young artists that becomes popular these days like Natalie Portman, Jack Black and Sarah Jessica Parker. Overall, 'Mars Attacks!' is not a film that audience would enjoy nowadays, the more years you watch it, the more you dislike this movie. It's different with classic movie like 'Godfather', 'Star Wars' or 'Jurassic Park' that never gets old and everyone could still enjoy even for future generation.

Review title: ALL-STAR CAST BLASTED INTO MULTI- COLORED SKELETONS
Review_body: "MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM-MEM!!!!!!!!!!!"translated:MARS ATTACKS is a lot of fun, that is, if you don't take it too seriously. Whether you loved or hated INDEPENDENCE DAY or WAR OF THE WORLDS for that matter, you may still appreciate MARS ATTACKS. Much better than PEE-WEE's BIG ADVENTURE or the PLANET OF THE APES remake."MEM-MEM: mememmemem  mim im memmemmemmemmem"Rating: **** out of *****

I hated this movie when it first came out. I couldn't stand it. I remember seeing a preview for it in theaters and going "that looks great!" Then I picked up the movie when it came out on VHS at the time and basically hated it with a passion. I wanted more destruction, more people to be disintegrated. I was rooting for the aliens inside. But about a year or so later it began to haunt me, scenes kept popping into my head. Soon I caught myself renting it every so often and I began to realize that I liked this movie. But I didn't realize that the great Tim Burton directed it till about 4 years ago. I have to say this has grown tremendously on me. The all star line up does help the movie as well. The story isn't anything complex; they want to destroy us. Nothing real special about the plot, but that's part of the beauty because it makes it very B-Horror. The movie is funny, violent, and overall is just a good time. Watch it more than once if you didn't like it the first time; it will grow on you.

Review title: They come in peace, and leave you in pieces
Review_body:
This cult classic is hilarious, and a must watch if you're in to splatter comedys. "Don't run, we are your friends" always tears me up :D
The special effects and animation hasn't aged very well since I saw it the first time, but that is also part of the charm!

I'd heard some fairly good things about this film despite being dubious of it when it first came out but last night I finally gave into the temptation and watched it. Let's just say I was fairly disappointed.The satire was good, I could definitely recognise the cheesy elements of old sci-fi 'shocker' flicks it was sending up despite not being an advocate of the genre but the fact is it doesn't make for good viewing. It's nothing more than just the same old corny, over-the-top acting and deliberately awful special effects (if one can even call them that) as the sort that director Tim Burton is trying to mock. All it leaves you with is a thought that says 'it was meant to be like that' even if it is terrible.For another thing, it is disappointing to see such a stellar cast reduced to such pointless acting. It's such a waste of talent to put Nicholson, Close, Brosnan, Benning among others in a film where rookies picked randomly off the street could do the same job for a much lower wage.And the film itself is difficult to watch because the direction and the script are truly awful, but it just leads me back to the too-oft-uttered phrase, "it's meant to be like that". All it really does is alienate the viewer rather than truly draw you into the experience, either as a sci-fi flick or as a comic satire.I think it's fair to say that the cast and crew had a lot more fun making this than we have watching it. 2 stars out of 5.

There is nothing good about this film. It tries so hard to be a black comedy. Like most of Tim Burton's films it is black dark. Mars Attacks! is one big spoof of 50's SCI FI flicks. It is also a spoof of Dr. Strangelove. Specificly, Rod Steiger's character.(Gen. Decker). This character acts alot like George C. Scott's character in Dr. Strangelove.People are always saying how bad some movies are, but the only people that I've ever heard say this are the critics. One Science Fiction movie I can compare this to is Plan 9 From Outer Space. Plan 9 is labled as the worst movie of all time, but it's so much better then Mars Attacks. Mars Attacks gets vaporized by any SCI FI movie in my book.Better luck next time Burton.

Review title: Parody Sci-Fi, interesting concept poorly executed
Review_body: UFOs get spotted in the skies over the US, the president decides to open up for them with disastrous results. This movie parodies the classic science fiction movies, Independence day, war of the worlds and Star Wars etc. Has a huge cast of popular actors with none of them getting the attention needed to really make them actual characters. Comedy wise it got a few laughs but I was a lot more weirded out at the strange visuals. One thing is for certain this movie is unique with it's aliens, the CGI really works with their design. The plot is bare bones and spends way too much time setting things up, leading to a rushed ending. Watch this if you are interested in the Alien design, if not skip it.

Mars Attacks... Hmmm... This is a movie you will either hate or like... I, myself, love it. It´s a wonderful creation of Tim Burton. The cast is wonderful, especially Nicholson, Bening and Close plus of course Rod Steiger. Martians, those green little bastards with their laser pistols, are great. Effects are otherwise fantastic too.I give this movie 10 out of 10. You have to see it yourself before judging it. You will either like it or not. Some people like movies like this, some people don´t. To find out if you like it, go get the video!!!!!!!!!!!!

It's been a while since I saw this movie, so I can't remember most of it, except the images of the Martians' brains bursting into little pieces. But I do remember that as one of the reasons why I hated this movie. Not only are the Martians ugly, they aren't even remotely AMUSING! And if this movie is supposed to be a parody of sci-fi flicks, then I'm sorry, it didn't work for me. I like Michael J. Fox but god, he was in this film? Since when?

Review title: A guilty pleasure that grows on you
Review_body: When I first saw this in the theater with my granddaughter, we both found to be pretty lame and disappointing, but not without some wit to it. Since then, it's been on the cable channels multiple times, and I always find myself watching it again. I really hate to admit it, but this thing has really grown on me - so much so that I finally bought the DVD.When I first saw it, I wouldn't have given it more than a 4 out of 10, but after repeated viewings, I now give it a 9. I can't really say why, and I certainly can't justify it in any rational sense, but it all just works for me. The wry wit, the blatant social and political commentary, I find it all immensely satisfying.My confession's over, I'll do my penance. But I have to also say that my granddaughter's opinion of it has never wavered. She considers this movie as evidence of my incipient senility...

Review title: Pretty good movie that confounds my expectations
Review_body: I've seen this so many times on cable. I can understand the people who dislike this movie but I definitely land on the side of the fans.I think this movie is Burton's one expensive joke on us where everything literally doesn't turn out the way we expect it. The big stars die left and right, and earth is left to be repopulated with Mrs. Warren Beatty, a Las Vegas showgirl and Tom Jones! That's an interesting twist on Adam and Eve and Jane. I guess I enjoyed being confounded, and part of my enjoyment are the other user comments who scratch their heads over this film.

Review title: A great way to totally waste your time
Review_body: When I first saw the listing of stars in this movie, I expected nothing less than a phenomenal movie. I mean, it's like they dredged Hollywood and just dumped the stars into this movie. It's a true who's who in the movies.But sadly, the movie was horrible. No, horrible is too good a word. How about putrid? That's getting better, but not quite there yet.Vile. Yeah, that's it. Vile. It is, without a doubt, one of the ten worst movies ever to waste screen space.Okay, there's one decent scene .. where Congress gets blown away. Yeah, I liked that. But the rest was a puke-fest.Save your money. Save your time. Save your mind. Avoid this movie!!

Review title: This just had to be a labor of fun and love -and not for the money!
Review_body: For sooooooo many top actors and personalities to sign-on for this tongue-in-cheek spoof, they didn't do it just because they needed to make a boat payment, or a mortgage payment was due on their 10th vacation home around the world, or the kids' need braces, or whatever.Seems they did it just for the fun. Great production values, direction, the script, the plot special effects, and the list goes on.Just fun to watch . And Silvia Sydney with her " Indian Love Call" record was especially terrific. She/they saved the world!

There are many people out there that just HATE this movie. That's understandable. It's cheesy, the special effects are not that great and ******SPOILER****** most of the cast dies. ***END OF SPOILER*** For these reasons and more, I loved this movie!!!!!! To those of you who think Tim Burton hit his low point on this movie, consider this. "Mars Attacks!" was an homage to all the cheesy Sci-Fi movies of the 50's and 60's. I think Burton knew exactly what he was doing. Obviously he has a soft spot in his heart for the director, Ed Wood. If you've ever seen an Ed Wood movie, or even the movie "Ed Wood" also directed by Burton, you'd know that cheesy sci-fi films are really a lot of fun. I think the problem with most people is that since the introduction to big budget special effects, people don't want to see effects that are less than spectacular. Honestly, I had not laughed at a movie in a long time before I saw "Mars Attacks!". ***SPOILER*** When I saw those cows on fire running down the street, I knew I was watching a classic movie. **END OF SPOILER** All I'm saying is don't go into this movie thinking of "Star Wars" or "Star Trek". Pretend you're reading The Weekly World News, and take this movie for how it was meant...ENTERTAINMENT!

Many people missed the point of this spoof...the mere fact that it was purely a joke seems to have been missed by some.  It was a joke and a funny one (my siblings and burst into laughter at the sound of "Dakk, Dakk, Dakk").  It drags in the beginning...but once we begin to get rid of the big stars, the movie begins to shine.  Love the casting of Joe Don Baker, Jim Brown, Pam Grier and Tom Jones. (The inclusion of footage from a Godzilla flick was great too).  Favorite moment from the film: when I realised that Tom Jones had a speaking part, not just a singing one, and was actually going to come to the rescue.  Jim Brown's tough ex-boxer was hilarious, made me feel like I was watching Slaughter or Three the Hard Way.

Remarkably apposite today in the aftermath of the ignoble storming of the Capitol: in one fell swoop with this Bush-era romp Burton encapsulates the entire fleet of American inanities and illusion of self-worth. The least offensive character is the deliciously ditzy Sylvia Sydney in her retirement home with the stuffed cat and her LP of Whitman's Indian Lovecall. A homage to Kubrick's Dr Strangelove and all those hammy 1950s sci-fi television series, even referencing Lumet's Failsafe, but also a riotous snub to all the movies in which the US saves the world (Independence Day, War of the Worlds, and the like). While the stateside stars clearly delight in the parody, the visionary overlapping ironies compound with the parallels between the Martian invasion and the current Covid-19 virus depopulating the planet with complete disregard for the protocols of democracy and the parade of self-appointed spokespeople. Burton takes the mickey also out of romance with the Brosnan/Parker equation and the sexist pap fed to the American public for decades. Martin Short and the gum-chewing inflatable moll with nothing to say goes even further into the American male psyche: "They call this the 'Kennedy Room', pretty nifty, huh?" The sacrilege continues unabated with the ensuing invasion of the White House, where it takes two shoot-up game-playing kids to show up the inadequacies of the President's protection detail and National Guard. The power of money in Vegas is likewise ridiculed. And what an elliptical stroke of genius to engage Tom Jones. The relatively low vote for this film suggests that most reviewers are white 'disenfranchised' American males offended when their sacrosanct yet vaguely understood ideals are lampooned. The finale on the devastated Capitol steps with a Mariachi band is the culmination of Burton's satirical look at his own country: the Proud Boys, QAnon, and the myriad Bundyites in every quarter of the "home of the brave". This pre-9/11 and pre-Trump romp has that evergreen pedigree of Groundhog Day. Let's not forget, "We come in peace, we are your friends."

This film takes the p*ss out of pretty much everything, is very whacky, absurd and - depending on your sense of humour - extremely funny. Don't watch if you take yourself or humankind too seriously. Quite unique, with wonderful B-movie vibe and stellar cast. Anarchic and biting wit throughout. Watch out for the nuke blow-back scene which is one of the funniest things I've ever seen on screen. Improves with repeated viewings. Recommended.

Review title: You'll love it or hate it.
Review_body: The tongue gets so far into the cheek with this film that there is a danger of choking. If you are after a plot-filled Sci-Fi adventure that will cause meaningful discussion on the Earth's relationships with distant beings....this is not for you. If you like a cheeky pup of a director using endless big-name stars to decorate a film devoted to excess then stay tuned. Tim Burton is a genius when good (Edward Scissorhands and The Nightmare Before Christmas) but he walks on very thin ice. For quite a lot of this film Tim has one foot, at least, getting very wet and very cold. Thankfully there are enough superbly memorable moments to justify the expense and our time. Just to watch the Alien invaders perish at the hands of Country and Western music is worth the entrance fee on its own!

Although it isn't often discussed, Mars Attacks! Is one of Tim Burton's best films. This is because it has the budget for all his creativity, yet isn't so preoccupied with image that it loses relatability. The story of an alien invasion is classic and ambitious, but there is enough heart peppered throughout the script to keep everything grounded. Meanwhile, the movie is very funny and stylish in ways that suit Burton best. Mars Attacks! Has a distinct retro-futuristic production design that Burton brings to life and makes the film unique.The look of everything is fantastic but it is the star-studded cast that is the most eye-catching. Mars Attacks! Is filled with bona fide A-listers like Jack Nicholson and up-and-comers like Jack Black. Additionally, the score perfectly captures the nostalgic homage of the movie, and the special effects are an excellent blend of CGI and practical (which synergize well). This helps unify the outrageous supernatural with the emotional accessibility. Balancing camp is always a tough act but Mars Attacks! Nails it flawlessly. Appropriate doses of humor and vulnerability, thorough vision, and skilled craftsmanship make this a movie for all audiences.Writing: 7/10
Direction: 9/10
Cinematography: 7/10
Acting: 7/10
Editing: 8/10
Sound: 8/10
Score/Soundtrack: 10/10
Production Design: 10/10
Casting: 10/10
Effects: 9/10Overall Score: 8.5/10.

Okay, let me start out with this. There are two boxes you could fit in with Mars Attacks. You either loved it and thought it was hilarious, or you hated it and were disappointed in Tim Burton. I am in a box, the one where you like the movie. Sure, it got a little too over-the-top, even for a movie trying to be over-the-top, and it didn't have the usual Tim Burton feeling to it that we have come to love. Still, the movie was hilarious! It made fun of every bad sci-fi movie of the '50's, and it was funny how they got such well known actors to play extremely pointless characters, such as Danny DeVito and Michael J. Fox. The movie had hysterical music done by the great Danny Elfman, and the acting was amusing because of everyone purposefully overacting. I really thought that the movie couldn't have been done better. I can't believe that some people thought that the movie was supposed to be a serious movie. I read one review where they were comparing this movie to Independance Day. Come on! Please don't tell me that they were actually serious when they wrote that. This movie was funny, a little misconcepted at times yeah, but still another good Tim Burton film.

Review title: Could have been so much more...
Review_body: When I first saw Mars Attacks! I admit I absolutely HATED it and thought it was the dumbest movie I had ever seen.  Amazingly, I initially found Ed Wood's "Plan Nine From Outer Space" more entertaining.  I'm not entirely sure what prompted me to do so, but I gave it a second viewing.  Don't get me wrong, I still thought it was dumb, but I had a better appreciation for the movie in general.With an incredible star (and talent) packed group of actors and actresses, the movie was still missing something...an incredibly big something. Although I enjoyed the nod to sci-fi's of the '50s and the B-movie type stylings, it still was not able to deliver.  Maybe it was the push of the "big named actors" to make this seem like it was going to be some phenomenal hit, or the fact that those same actors never quite played up to THEIR potential.  But what I really think caused the problem was the incredibly bad timing.  No, not in its release, but in the movie itself.  So many jokes fell flat simply because they were delivered far too late, and the use of comedic repition was, well, *too* repititious.  I think many viewers who are die-hard fans of b-movie or 50's sci-fi will probably appreciate Mars Attacks much better than I.  And although it has some entertaining moments, it just didn't quite become what it could have. I give it a 5 out of 10 stars...it truly was just mediocre.

Review title: A blast with a blast from the past.
Review_body: I just love this movie!! It's a cult classic and unless you are a Tim Burton or fan of the litany of Sci-Fi abominations from the 50's, it's hard to appreciate his vision. I think if he had the time to fine tune it (thanks to the studio wanting an earlier release), it likely would have done better.Easter eggs abound and one of the best casts anyone could ask for. Many have worked in other projects of his. If you watch it as many times as I have over the, yikes, 25 YEARS since it's release, you still pick up on things.It's one of those rare movies that the Goofs could be taken as a "goof" on the blatant errors the old movies made, especially Ed Wood movies. It would have been hilarious if they added wires to the saucers that was so obvious in Plan 9 From Outer Space, for example.You know a director has clout when they can get the great actors, many of them still quite relevant now, to appear in an homage SciFi picture. To me it's only a bit dated by the handful of people that aren't in the limelight anymore or those who passed a while back.The funniest scenes are the little guys lounging in their tiny red Speedos (on humans, they are ghastly and, well, gross), their Ack, Ack, Acking and Grandma with her Slim Whitman music.You can't take this movie seriously, it's not meant to be. In regard to one review; you aren't dumb for watching it-and spell the word "you" not "u"; that's dumb!!! I mean, come on.

Review title: Lots of famous actors in a movie.
Review_body: The only rewarding aspect of this yawner is watching the talented actors forced to wrestle with the wretched parts they mistakenly agreed to play.As sci-fi it's unimaginative. As comedy it's droll. As entertainment it stinks.God knows what the aim of this was.
This is seriously stupid movie even for tim burton. Like wooow bad really really bad

Review title: Where is the line between campiness and spoofing campiness
Review_body: Tim Burton takes an A-list cast including Jack Nicholson, Glenn Close, Natalie Portman, Sarah Jessica Parker, Jack Black in an early role, Rod Steiger, Michael J. Fox and several others and attempts to send up the cheap, campy science fiction movies of the 50 and 60s. I think he watched too many Ed Wood movies and had this idea spring forth fully formed from his forehead.Martians attack the earth, pretend to be friendly and then start zapping earthlings and wreaking destruction far and wide. My favorite part: When the martians get the translator machine and carry it around with them shouting, do not run, we are your friends, while simultaneously zapping everyone they see. It's campy and clichéd as was intended. The question is though, what makes a spoof of something superior to what it is spoofing? This movie is like green jello with shaved carrots made in a mold to resemble a clover and served at an upscale party to mock the parochial bourgeois of the midwest and Utah. Everyone has a good laugh and samples a bit to understand what it means to have such poor taste. But all said and done, it is still green jello with carrots shaved into it, and it's not that good and it is midwest potluck food (I've lived near Des Moines and Salt Lake City and know plenty about jello) and although done in the spirit of mockery or spoof, doesn't taste any better than the real thing which wasn't that good to begin with. 5/10

"Mars Attacks!" makes a great video double-feature with (and antidote to) another Warner Brothers effort, "Contact."  The latter is much less impressive on videocassette, while "Mars Attacks!" gains immensely from more intimate viewing conditions.  It's really fun weekend TV schlock, made by clever minds; "Contact" loses a lot of its grandeur but retains its saccharine mass appeal.  Combine the two, and enjoy the nice balance, and the contrasts.

Review title: It would be hard to make a movie this bad even if people tried to make a bad movie.
Review_body: The only movie where there was nothing good. At least Wild Wild Crap West ) had few interesting gadgets.A better ending for the movie would have been if instead of playing that music to kill Martians, they had shown them the beginning of this movie. That would have wiped them out much more easily.

Review title: Too many bits, not enough whole
Review_body: I guess that's what you get when you base a film on a trading card set. It's almost as if each bit was meant to be taken as a card in the set.I'm all for a good parody but I have to agree with the people who point to the original(s) sometimes being funnier than the parody.

Review title: One of the worst movies I've ever scene! Waste of time, money to make, and just plain stupid!
Review_body: Yes this movie is a comedy and a B movie so you're not supposed to take it seriously. This movie was beyond bad, it was terrible! It lagged on, the Aliens sounded stupid and the special effects were too cheesy. The idiocy of the characters was beyond my tolerance for stupidity. Good actors doing bad acting. I've seen black and white B movies better than this! Why? Just why?

Review title: Surprisingly, a real treat -- a genuine loving parody
Review_body: I first saw this movie when I was sixteen or so, not long after it came out on video. I feel sure the people who rented it only did so because of the "A-list" actors. I don't think they really "got it" and, at the time, I'm not sure I did either.over the years since then an interesting thing happened: I ended up watching this about four more times, twice when it just happened to be on and twice (the most recent times) through personal choice. It's safe to say that the damn thing just grew on me like insidious Martian mould. In 1996, I was really into science fiction, but more the "literary" stuff than silly old movies. I was a bit pompous about it all, in fact, so while I did kind of get a kick out of the movie the first time, mostly I just thought, "well, that's pretty silly, and surprisingly -- old-school!" and never really gave it much more consideration. With each subsequent viewing though, my immersion in old SF televisual classics and so-called b-movies had grown greater and certain things about this movie started to make a kind of ghastly, irreverent sense. I choose to just forget about the film being based on some old trading card series; I don't know anything about them, and maybe I'm missing out on something, but I think mars Attacks! works very well regardless as a kind of send-up of very serious and grave 50s and 60s low-budget SF "schlockfests".The funny thing is, I like a lot of those old movies, and I like them unreservedly. I don't find the form to be automatically "cheesy", too talky, too earnest, or anything like that. And I'm not a huge fan of parody for its own sake. usually, in fact, it leaves me cold at best, and a bit angry at worst, as peoples' hard work and dedication is lamppooned for a new generation with little sense of taste or respect. It's easy to be really contemptuous about mars Attacks!, and I think that was part of my initial impulse. I just didn't see the point in putting an "a-list" cast and director to work on what was essentially a copy of a plot from a 1950s B movie. Jack Nicholson's salary from this film alone might have financed two of those pictures!But then I thought about it a bit more. 1996 was the year Independence Day came out, too, after all. And what was this movie, this ridiculous blockbuster with the at-the-time state-of-the-art special effects and jumped-up movie stars, but a retread of 1956's Earth VS. the Flying Saucers? In fact, what were a lot of these big blockbuster movies but more expensive takes on what guys like Roger Corman, Val Guest and, yes, Ed Wood, had already done? Were they better just because they had a whole lot of money spent on them? NO!So, mars Attacks! is different because it's bald-faced about it, and that's really the extent of the parody. The more things change, the more they stay the same. The actors here know they're in a silly movie, and they're allowed to have fun. Nobody's expected to pretend this movie is anything other than what it is: a total unrepentent blast from the past.Sure, the ending is completely retarded. But it's ok as it's totally in keeping with the form! I like the build-up a lot. I enjoy the ridiculous stereotype characters, especially Ron Stiger's screaming red-in-the-face, practically foaming-at-the-mouth warmonger general. Jack nicholson as US President is so grave and sincere, it's hilarious; bang-up job from him, too. And there are so many adorable little cameos, gags and tributes. The music is nothing but loud warbly electronics done on an old synthesiser and it's the kind of thing that's both a terrific call-back to films of yore and something to annoy bothersome houseguests with. Tim Burton and Danny Elfman seem to have this relationship of trust going consistently, and I'm glad they went with this score instead of the normal bombastic stuff from sci-fi blockbusters of the 90s and beyond. About the gags, there are just too many to list, and a lot of them are over so quick you could easily miss them. This makes the movie have a nice re-play value, though, and is probably why I was always tempted to re-watch it even when my initial judgment was "kind of bad!". I haven't even talked about the aliens. They're ridiculous and awesome. I love their perpetually pissed-off duck-quack talking. They seem to have a sense of humour even though they're hell-bent on killing everyone. And I'm sorry I can't remember the name of the IMDB reviewer who said this, but I just love the notion (which I just came across the other day here after watching again) that the martians set out to destroy everything "uncool" about humanity. I never thought of it like that before, and I think he might be on to something!I also have to respect that even though Tim Burton got together a whole bunch of top-bill actors, everyone was not only (presumably) on board with the project, but most of them agreed to get killed off in sudden and undignified ways. I don't think anyone's acting chops were exactly stretched making this movie, but I hope everyone had a good time and enjoyed their cameos and generic parts and laughed along when they were dispatched. This is a rare beast for sure: a self-aware and slightly smug 1990s movie that still managed to win me over and put several big grins on my face. Try it!
